6.2.12.A.3.c [9-12] - Analyze the relationship between industrialization and the rise of democratic and social reforms, including the expansion of parliamentary government.
6.2.12.A.3.d [9-12] - Compare and contrast the struggles for women's suffrage and workers' rights in Europe and North America, and evaluate the degree to which each movement achieved its goals.

6.2.12.A.3.e [9-12] - Analyze the motives for and methods by which European nations, Japan, and the United States expanded their imperialistic practices in Africa and Asia during this era, and evaluate the impact of these actions on their relations.
6.2.12.B.3.a [9-12] - Assess the impact of imperialism by comparing and contrasting the political boundaries of the world in 1815 and 1914.
6.2.12.B.3.b [9-12] - Relate the role of geography to the spread of independence movements in Latin America.
6.2.12.C.3.a [9-12] - Analyze interrelationships among the "agricultural revolution," population growth, industrialization, specialization of labor, and patterns of land-holding.
6.2.12.C.3.b [9-12] - Analyze interrelationships among the Industrial Revolution, nationalism, competition for global markets, imperialism, and natural resources.
6.2.12.C.3.c [9-12] - Compare the characteristics of capitalism, communism, and socialism to determine why each system emerged in different world regions.

6.2.12.C.3.d [9-12] - Determine how, and the extent to which, scientific and technological changes, transportation, and new forms of energy brought about massive social, economic, and cultural changes.

6.2.12.C.3.e [9-12] - Compare the impact of imperialism on economic development in Africa, Asia, and Latin America regarding barriers or opportunities for future development and political independence.
6.2.12.D.3.a [9-12] - Explain how individuals and groups promoted revolutionary actions and brought about change during this time period.
6.2.12.D.3.b [9-12] - Explain how industrialization and urbanization affected class structure, family life, the daily lives of men, women, and children, and the environment.

6.2.12.D.3.c [9-12] - Compare and contrast China's and Japan's views of and responses to imperialism, and determine the effects of imperialism on the development and prosperity of each country in the 20th century.
6.2.12.D.3.d [9-12] - Analyze the extent to which racism was both a cause and consequence of imperialism, and evaluate the impact of imperialism from multiple perspectives.
6.2.12.D.3.e [9-12] - Analyze the impact of the policies of different European colonizers on indigenous societies, and explain the responses of these societies to imperialistic rule.
[9-12] - A Half-Century of Crisis and Achievement (1900-1945)

[9-12] - The Era of the Great Wars: Nationalism, imperialism, industrialization, and militarism contributed to an increase in economic and military competition among European nations, the Ottoman Empire, and Japan, and led to World War I. The failure of the Treaty of Versailles, the impact of the global depression, and the expansionist policies and actions of Axis nations are viewed as major factors that resulted in World War II. World Wars I and II were "total wars" in which nations mobilized entire populations and economies and employed new military tactics that resulted in unprecedented death and destruction, as well as drastic changes in political boundaries. World Wars I and II challenged economic and political power structures and gave rise to a new balance of power in the world. Economic, technological, and military power and bureaucracies have been used by nations to deliberately and systematically destroy ethnic/racial, political, and cultural groups.
6.2.12.A.4.a [9-12] - Explain the differences between socialism, communism, and fascism and explain the reasons for their spread in Europe and Asia.
6.2.12.A.4.b [9-12] - Compare the rise of nationalism in China, Turkey, and India.
6.2.12.A.4.c [9-12] - Analyze the motivations, causes, and consequences of the genocides of Armenians, Roma (gypsies), and Jews, as well as the mass exterminations of Ukrainians and Chinese.
6.2.12.A.4.d [9-12] - Assess government responses to incidents of ethnic cleansing and genocide.
6.2.12.B.4.a [9-12] - Determine the geographic impact of World War I by comparing and contrasting the political boundaries of the world in 1914 and 1939.
6.2.12.B.4.b [9-12] - Determine how geography impacted military strategies and major turning points during World War II.
6.2.12.B.4.c [9-12] - Explain how the disintegration of the Ottoman empire and the mandate system led to the creation of new nations in the Middle East.
6.2.12.B.4.d [9-12] - Explain the intended and unintended consequences of new national boundaries established by the treaties that ended World War II.

6.2.12.C.4.a [9-12] - Analyze government responses to the Great Depression and their consequences, including the growth of fascist, socialist, and communist movements and the effects on capitalist economic theory and practice.

6.2.12.C.4.b [9-12] - Compare and contrast World Wars I and II in terms of technological innovations (i.e., industrial production, scientific research, war tactics) and social impact (i.e., national mobilization, loss of life, and destruction of property).
6.2.12.C.4.c [9-12] - Assess the short- and long-term demographic, social, economic, and environmental consequences of the violence and destruction of the two World Wars.

6.2.12.C.4.d [9-12] - Analyze the ways in which new forms of communication, transportation, and weaponry affected relationships between governments and their citizens and bolstered the power of new authoritarian regimes during this period.
6.2.12.D.4.a [9-12] - Analyze the extent to which nationalism, industrialization, territory disputes, imperialism, militarism, and alliances led to World War I.
6.2.12.D.4.b [9-12] - Analyze the Treaty of Versailles and the League of Nations from the perspectives of different nations.
6.2.12.D.4.c [9-12] - Assess the causes of revolution in the 20th century (i.e., in Russia, China, India, and Cuba), and determine the impact on global politics.

6.2.12.D.4.d [9-12] - Analyze the extent to which the legacy of World War I, the global depression, ethnic and ideological conflicts, imperialism, and traditional political or economic rivalries caused World War II.
6.2.12.D.4.e [9-12] - Compare how Allied countries responded to the expansionist actions of Germany and Italy.
6.2.12.D.4.f [9-12] - Explain the role of colonial peoples in the war efforts of the Allies and the Central/Axis Powers in both World Wars.
6.2.12.D.4.g [9-12] - Analyze the role of racial bias, nationalism, and propaganda in mobilizing civilian populations in support of "total war".

6.2.12.D.4.h [9-12] - Assess the extent to which world war, depression, nationalist ideology, communism, and liberal democratic ideals contributed to the emergence of movements for national self-rule or sovereignty in Africa and Asia.

6.2.12.D.4.i [9-12] - Compare and contrast the actions of individuals as perpetrators, bystanders, and rescuers during events of persecution or genocide, and describe the long-term consequences of genocide for all involved.
6.2.12.D.4.j [9-12] - Analyze how the social, economic, and political roles of women were transformed during this time period.
6.2.12.D.4.k [9-12] - Assess the cultural impact of World War I, the Great Depression, and World War II by analyzing the values and social ideas in the arts.

[9-12] - Challenges for the Modern World: Decolonization, the emergence of new independent nations, and competing ideologies changed the political landscape and national identities of those involved, and sometimes included military confrontations and violations of human rights. International migration and scientific and technological improvements in the second half of the 20th century resulted in an increasingly global economy and society that are challenged by limited natural resources.

6.2.12.A.5.a [9-12] - Explain how and why differences in ideologies and policies between the United States and the USSR resulted in a cold war, the formation of new alliances (e.g., NATO, SEATO, Warsaw Pact), and periodic military clashes (e.g., Korean War, conflicts in the Middle East).
6.2.12.A.5.b [9-12] - Analyze the structure and goals of the United Nations and evaluate the organization's ability to solve or mediate international conflicts.
6.2.12.A.5.c [9-12] - Explain how World War II led to aspirations for self-determination, and compare and contrast the methods used by African and Asian countries to achieve independence.

6.2.12.A.5.d [9-12] - Analyze the causes and consequences of mass killings (e.g., Cambodia, Rwanda, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Somalia, Sudan), and evaluate the responsibilities of the world community in response to such events.
6.2.12.A.5.e [9-12] - Assess the progress of human and civil rights around the world since the 1948 U.N. Declaration of Human Rights.
6.2.12.B.5.a [9-12] - Determine the impact of geography on decisions made by the Soviet Union and the United States to expand and protect their spheres of influence.
6.2.12.B.5.b [9-12] - Analyze the reasons for the Cold War and the collapse of the Soviet Union, and evaluate the impact of these events on changing national boundaries in Eastern Europe and Asia.
6.2.12.B.5.c [9-12] - Determine the impact of migration on the way of life (e.g., social, economic, and political structures) in countries of origin and in adopted countries.

6.2.12.B.5.d [9-12] - Analyze post-independence struggles in South Asia, including the struggle over the partitioning of the subcontinent into India and Pakistan, as well as later tensions over Kashmir.
6.2.12.B.5.e [9-12] - Assess the role of boundary disputes and limited natural resources as sources of conflict.
6.2.12.C.5.a [9-12] - Explain how and why Western European countries and Japan achieved rapid economic recovery after World War II.
6.2.12.C.5.b [9-12] - Compare and contrast free market capitalism, Western European democratic socialism, and Soviet communism.
6.2.12.C.5.c [9-12] - Assess the impact of the international arms race, the space race, and nuclear proliferation on international politics from multiple perspectives.
6.2.12.C.5.d [9-12] - Determine the challenges faced by developing nations in their efforts to compete in a global economy.
6.2.12.C.5.e [9-12] - Assess the reasons for and consequences of the growth of communism and shift toward a market economy in China.
6.2.12.C.5.f [9-12] - Assess the impact of the European Union on member nations and other nations.
6.2.12.C.5.g [9-12] - Evaluate the role of the petroleum industry in world politics, the global economy, and the environment.
6.2.12.D.5.a [9-12] - Relate the lingering effects of colonialism to the efforts of Latin American, African, and Asian nations to build stable economies and national identities.
6.2.12.D.5.b [9-12] - Assess the impact of Gandhi's methods of civil disobedience and passive resistance in India, and determine how his methods were later used by people from other countries.
6.2.12.D.5.c [9-12] - Assess the influence of television, the Internet, and other forms of electronic communication on the creation and diffusion of cultural and political information, worldwide.

6.2.12.D.5.d [9-12] - Analyze how feminist movements and social conditions have affected the lives of women in different parts of the world, and evaluate women's progress toward social equality, economic equality, and political equality in various countries.

[9-12] - Contemporary Issues: Technological innovation, economic interdependence, changes in population growth, migratory patterns, and the development, distribution, and use of natural resources offer challenges and opportunities that transcend regional and national borders.
6.2.12.A.6.a [9-12] - Evaluate the role of international cooperation and multinational organizations in attempting to solve global issues.

6.2.12.A.6.b [9-12] - Analyze the relationships and tensions between national sovereignty and global interest in matters such as territory, economic development, use of natural resources, and human rights.
6.2.12.A.6.c [9-12] - Analyze why terrorist movements have proliferated, and evaluate their impact on governments, individuals, and societies.
6.2.12.A.6.d [9-12] - Assess the effectiveness of responses by governments and international organizations to tensions resulting from ethnic, territorial, religious, and/or nationalist differences.
6.2.12.B.6.a [9-12] - Determine the global impact of increased population growth, migration, and changes in urban-rural populations on natural resources and land use.
6.2.12.C.6.a [9-12] - Evaluate efforts of governmental, nongovernmental, and international organizations to address economic imbalances and social inequalities.

6.2.12.C.6.b [9-12] - Compare and contrast demographic trends in industrialized and developing nations, and evaluate the potential impact of these trends on the economy, political stability, and use of resources.
6.2.12.C.6.c [9-12] - Assess the role government monetary policies, central banks, international investment, and exchange rates play in maintaining stable regional and global economies.
6.2.12.C.6.d [9-12] - Determine how the availability of scientific, technological, and medical advances impacts the quality of life in different countries.
6.2.12.D.6.a [9-12] - Assess the role of increased personal and business electronic communications in creating a "global" culture, and evaluate the impact on traditional cultures and values.

[K-12] - Active Citizenship in the 21st Century: All students will acquire the skills needed to be active, informed citizens who value diversity and promote cultural understanding by working collaboratively to address the challenges that are inherent in living in an interconnected world.

[K-4] - Active citizens in the 21st century:
  • Recognize that people have different perspectives based on their beliefs, values, traditions, culture, and experiences.
  • Identify stereotyping, bias, prejudice, and discrimination in their lives and communities.
  • Are aware of their relationships to people, places, and resources in the local community and beyond.
  • Make informed and reasoned decisions by seeking and assessing information, asking questions, and evaluating alternate solutions.
  • Develop strategies to reach consensus and resolve conflict.
  • Demonstrate understanding of the need for fairness and take appropriate action against unfairness.
6.3.4.A.1 [K-4] - Determine what makes a good rule or law and apply this understanding to rules and laws in your school or community (e.g., bike helmet, recycling).
6.3.4.A.2 [K-4] - Examine the impact of a local issue by considering the perspectives of different groups, including community members and local officials.
6.3.4.A.3 [K-4] - Select a local issue and develop a group action plan to inform school and/or community members about the issue.
6.3.4.A.4 [K-4] - Communicate with students from various countries about common issues of public concern and possible solutions.
6.3.4.B.1 [K-4] - Plan and participate in an advocacy project to inform others about environmental issues at the local or state level and propose possible solutions.
6.3.4.C.1 [K-4] - Develop and implement a group initiative that addresses an economic issue impacting children.
6.3.4.D.1 [K-4] - Identify actions that are unfair or discriminatory, such as bullying, and propose solutions to address such actions.

[5-8] - Active citizens in the 21st century:
  • Recognize the causes and effects of prejudice on individuals, groups, and society.
  • Recognize the value of cultural diversity, as well as the potential for misunderstanding.
  • Critically analyze media to assess different viewpoints and detect bias, opinion, and stereotypes.
  • Listen open-mindedly to views contrary to their own.
  • Collaboratively develop and practice strategies for managing and resolving conflict.
  • Demonstrate understanding of democratic values and processes.
  • Recognize that the actions or inactions of individuals, groups, and nations can have intended and unintended consequences.
  • Challenge unfair viewpoints and behaviors by taking action.
  • Make informed and reasoned decisions.
  • Accept decisions that are made for the common good.
6.3.8.A.1 [5-8] - Deliberate on a public issue affecting an upcoming election, consider opposing arguments, and develop a reasoned conclusion.

6.3.8.A.2 [5-8] - Participate in a real or simulated hearing to develop a legislative proposal that addresses a public issue, and share it with an appropriate legislative body (e.g., school board, municipal or county government, state legislature).
6.3.8.A.3 [5-8] - Collaborate with international students to deliberate about and address issues of gender equality, child mortality, or education.
6.3.8.B.1 [5-8] - Evaluate alternative land use proposals and make recommendations to the appropriate governmental agency regarding the best course of action.
6.3.8.C.1 [5-8] - Examine the perspectives of multiple stakeholders involved in the local budget process (e.g., obtaining information, discussing priorities).

6.3.8.D.1 [5-8] - Engage in simulated democratic processes (e.g., legislative hearings, judicial proceedings, elections) to understand how conflicting points of view are addressed in a democratic society.

[9-12] - Active citizens in the 21st century:
  • Determine the credibility and value of information, while also considering context, point of view, and multiple perspectives.
  • Analyze sources of prejudice and discrimination and propose solutions to eliminate them.
  • Collaboratively evaluate possible solutions to problems and conflicts that arise in an interconnected world.
  • Critically analyze information, make ethical judgments, and responsibly address controversial issues.
  • Communicate through rational and persuasive written and oral arguments to present solutions to controversial issues.
  • Make informed and reasoned decisions and accept responsibility for the consequences of their actions and/or inactions.
  • Take actions that result in a more just and equitable society.
6.3.12.A.1 [9-12] - Develop a plan for public accountability and transparency in government related to a particular issue(s) and share the plan with appropriate government officials.

6.3.12.A.2 [9-12] - Compare current case studies involving slavery, child labor, or other unfair labor practices in the United States with those of other nations, and evaluate the extent to which such problems are universal.

6.3.12.B.1 [9-12] - Collaborate with students from other countries to develop possible solutions to an issue of environmental justice, and present those solutions to relevant national and international governmental and/or nongovernmental organizations.

6.3.12.C.1 [9-12] - Participate in a simulated meeting (e.g., President's Council, World Bank, International Monetary Fund (IMF)), research evidence from multiple sources about an economic problem, (e.g., inflation, unemployment, deficit), and develop a plan of action.
6.3.12.D.1 [9-12] - Analyze the impact of current governmental practices and laws affecting national security and/or individual civil rights/ privacy.
6.3.12.D.2 [9-12] - Analyze a current foreign policy issue by considering current and historical perspectives, examining strategies, and presenting possible actions.
MI - Biology High School Content Expectations
B1 [9-12] - Inquiry, Reflection, and Social Implications
B1.1A [9-12] - Generate new questions that can be investigated in the laboratory or field.

B1.1B [9-12] - Evaluate the uncertainties or validity of scientific conclusions using an understanding of sources of measurement error, the challenges of controlling variables, accuracy of data analysis, logic of argument, logic of experimental design, and/or the dependence on underlying assumptions.

B1.1C [9-12] - Conduct scientific investigations using appropriate tools and techniques (e.g., selecting an instrument that measures the desired quantity—length, volume, weight, time interval, temperature—with the appropriate level of precision).
B1.1D [9-12] - Identify patterns in data and relate them to theoretical models.
B1.1E [9-12] - Describe a reason for a given conclusion using evidence from an investigation.
B1.1f [9-12] - Predict what would happen if the variables, methods, or timing of an investigation were changed.
B1.1g [9-12] - Use empirical evidence to explain and critique the reasoning used to draw a scientific conclusion or explanation.
B1.1h [9-12] - Design and conduct a systematic scientific investigation that tests a hypothesis. Draw conclusions from data presented in charts or tables.
B1.1i [9-12] - Distinguish between scientific explanations that are regarded as current scientific consensus and the emerging questions that active researchers investigate.
B1.2 [9-12] - Scientific Reflection and Social Implications
B1.2A [9-12] - Critique whether or not specific questions can be answered through scientific investigations.
B1.2B [9-12] - Identify and critique arguments about personal or societal issues based on scientific evidence.
B1.2C [9-12] - Develop an understanding of a scientific concept by accessing information from multiple sources. Evaluate the scientific accuracy and significance of the information.
B1.2D [9-12] - Evaluate scientific explanations in a peer review process or discussion format.
B1.2E [9-12] - Evaluate the future career and occupational prospects of science fields.
B1.2f [9-12] - Critique solutions to problems, given criteria and scientific constraints.
B1.2g [9-12] - Identify scientific tradeoffs in design decisions and choose among alternative solutions.
B1.2h [9-12] - Describe the distinctions between scientific theories, laws, hypotheses, and observations.
B1.2i [9-12] - Explain the progression of ideas and explanations that leads to science theories that are part of the current scientific consensus or core knowledge.
B1.2j [9-12] - Apply science principles or scientific data to anticipate effects of technological design decisions.
B1.2k [9-12] - Analyze how science and society interact from a historical, political, economic, or social perspective.
B2 [9-12] - Organization and Development of Living Systems
L2.p1A [9-12] - Distinguish between living and nonliving systems. (prerequisite)
L2.p1B [9-12] - Explain the importance of both water and the element carbon to cells. (prerequisite)
L2.p1C [9-12] - Describe growth and development in terms of increase in cell number, cell size, and/or cell products. (prerequisite)
L2.p1D [9-12] - Explain how the systems in a multicellular organism work together to support the organism. (prerequisite)
L2.p1E [9-12] - Compare and contrast how different organisms accomplish similar functions (e.g., obtain oxygen for respiration, and excrete waste). (prerequisite)
L2.p2A [9-12] - Describe how organisms sustain life by obtaining, transporting, transforming, releasing, and eliminating matter and energy. (prerequisite)
L2.p2B [9-12] - Describe the effect of limiting food to developing cells. (prerequisite)
L2.p3A [9-12] - Explain the significance of carbon in organic molecules. (prerequisite)
L2.p3B [9-12] - Explain the origins of plant mass. (prerequisite)
L2.p3C [9-12] - Predict what would happen to plants growing in low carbon dioxide atmospheres. (prerequisite)
L2.p3D [9-12] - Explain how the roots of specific plants grow. (prerequisite)
L2.p4A [9-12] - Classify different organisms based on how they obtain energy for growth and development. (prerequisite)
L2.p4B [9-12] - Explain how an organism obtains energy from the food it consumes. (prerequisite)
L2.p5A [9-12] - Recognize the six most common elements in organic molecules (C, H, N, O, P, S). (prerequisite)
L2.p5B [9-12] - Identify the most common complex molecules that make up living organisms. (prerequisite)
L2.p5C [9-12] - Predict what would happen if essential elements were withheld from developing cells. (prerequisite)
B2.1 [9-12] - Transformation of Matter and Energy in Cells

B2.1A [9-12] - Explain how cells transform energy (ultimately obtained from the sun) from one form to another through the processes of photosynthesis and respiration. Identify the reactants and products in the general reaction of photosynthesis.
B2.1B [9-12] - Compare and contrast the transformation of matter and energy during photosynthesis and respiration.
B2.1C [9-12] - Explain cell division, growth, and development as a consequence of an increase in cell number, cell size, and/or cell products.
B2.1d [9-12] - Describe how, through cell division, cells can become specialized for specific function.
B2.1e [9-12] - Predict what would happen if the cells from one part of a developing embryo were transplanted to another part of the embryo.
B2.2A [9-12] - Explain how carbon can join to other carbon atoms in chains and rings to form large and complex molecules.
B2.2B [9-12] - Recognize the six most common elements in organic molecules (C, H, N, O, P, S).
B2.2C [9-12] - Describe the composition of the four major categories of organic molecules (carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids).
B2.2D [9-12] - Explain the general structure and primary functions of the major complex organic molecules that compose living organisms.
B2.2E [9-12] - Describe how dehydration and hydrolysis relate to organic molecules.
B2.2f [9-12] - Explain the role of enzymes and other proteins in biochemical functions (e.g., the protein hemoglobin carries oxygen in some organisms, digestive enzymes, and hormones).
B2.2g [9-12] - Propose how moving an organism to a new environment may influence its ability to survive and predict the possible impact of this type of transfer.
B2.3A [9-12] - Describe how cells function in a narrow range of physical conditions, such as temperature and pH (acidity), to perform life functions.
B2.3B [9-12] - Describe how the maintenance of a relatively stable internal environment is required for the continuation of life.
B2.3C [9-12] - Explain how stability is challenged by changing physical, chemical, and environmental conditions as well as the presence of disease agents.

B2.3d [9-12] - Identify the general functions of the major systems of the human body (digestion, respiration, reproduction, circulation, excretion, protection from disease, and movement, control, and coordination) and describe ways that these systems interact with each other.
B2.3e [9-12] - Describe how human body systems maintain relatively constant internal conditions (temperature, acidity, and blood sugar).
B2.3f [9-12] - Explain how human organ systems help maintain human health.
B2.3g [9-12] - Compare the structure and function of a human body system or subsystem to a nonliving system (e.g., human joints to hinges, enzyme and substrate to interlocking puzzle pieces).
B2.4A [9-12] - Explain that living things can be classified based on structural, embryological, and molecular (relatedness of DNA sequence) evidence.

B2.4B [9-12] - Describe how various organisms have developed different specializations to accomplish a particular function and yet the end result is the same (e.g., excreting nitrogenous wastes in animals, obtaining oxygen for respiration).
B2.4C [9-12] - Explain how different organisms accomplish the same result using different structural specializations (gills vs. lungs vs. membranes).
B2.4d [9-12] - Analyze the relationships among organisms based on their shared physical, biochemical, genetic, and cellular characteristics and functional processes.
B2.4e [9-12] - Explain how cellular respiration is important for the production of ATP (build on aerobic vs. anaerobic).

B2.4f [9-12] - Recognize and describe that both living and nonliving things are composed of compounds, which are themselves made up of elements joined by energy-containing bonds, such as those in ATP.
B2.4g [9-12] - Explain that some structures in the modern eukaryotic cell developed from early prokaryotes, such as mitochondria, and in plants, chloroplasts.
B2.4h [9-12] - Describe the structures of viruses and bacteria.
B2.4i [9-12] - Recognize that while viruses lack cellular structure, they have the genetic material to invade living cells.
B2.5A [9-12] - Recognize and explain that macromolecules such as lipids contain high energy bonds.

B2.5B [9-12] - Explain how major systems and processes work together in animals and plants, including relationships between organelles, cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, and organisms. Relate these to molecular functions.
B2.5C [9-12] - Describe how energy is transferred and transformed from the Sun to energy-rich molecules during photosynthesis.
B2.5D [9-12] - Describe how individual cells break down energy-rich molecules to provide energy for cell functions.
B2.5e [9-12] - Explain the interrelated nature of photosynthesis and cellular respiration in terms of ATP synthesis and degradation.
B2.5f [9-12] - Relate plant structures and functions to the process of photosynthesis and respiration.
B2.5g [9-12] - Compare and contrast plant and animal cells.
B2.5h [9-12] - Explain the role of cell membranes as a highly selective barrier (diffusion, osmosis, and active transport).
B2.5i [9-12] - Relate cell parts/organelles to their function.
B2.6a [9-12] - Explain that the regulatory and behavioral responses of an organism to external stimuli occur in order to maintain both short- and long-term equilibrium.

B2.r6b [9-12] - Explain that complex interactions among the different kinds of molecules in the cell cause distinct cycles of activities, such as growth and division. Note that cell behavior can also be affected by molecules from other parts of the organism, such as hormones. (recommended)
B2.r6c [9-12] - Recognize and explain that communication and/or interaction are required between cells to coordinate their diverse activities. (recommended)

B2.r6d [9-12] - Explain how higher levels of organization result from specific complex interactions of smaller units and that their maintenance requires a constant input of energy as well as new material. (recommended)
B2.r6e [9-12] - Analyze the body's response to medical interventions such as organ transplants, medicines, and inoculations. (recommended)
B3 [9-12] - Interdependence of Living Systems and the Environment
L3.p1A [9-12] - Provide examples of a population, community, and ecosystem. (prerequisite)
L3.p2A [9-12] - Describe common relationships among organisms and provide examples of producer/consumer, predator/prey, or parasite/host relationship. (prerequisite)

L3.p2B [9-12] - Describe common ecological relationships between and among species and their environments (competition, territory, carrying capacity, natural balance, population, dependence, survival, and other biotic and abiotic factors). (prerequisite)
L3.p2C [9-12] - Describe the role of decomposers in the transfer of energy in an ecosystem. (prerequisite)
L3.p2D [9-12] - Explain how two organisms can be mutually beneficial and how that can lead to interdependency. (prerequisite)
L3.p3A [9-12] - Identify the factors in an ecosystem that influence fluctuations in population size. (prerequisite)
L3.p3B [9-12] - Distinguish between the living (biotic) and nonliving (abiotic) components of an ecosystem. (prerequisite)
L3.p3C [9-12] - Explain how biotic and abiotic factors cycle in an ecosystem (water, carbon, oxygen, and nitrogen). (prerequisite)
L3.p3D [9-12] - Predict how changes in one population might affect other populations based upon their relationships in a food web. (prerequisite)

L3.p4A [9-12] - Recognize that, and describe how, human beings are part of Earth's ecosystems. Note that human activities can deliberately or inadvertently alter the equilibrium in ecosystems. (prerequisite)
B3.1A [9-12] - Describe how organisms acquire energy directly or indirectly from sunlight.
B3.1B [9-12] - Illustrate and describe the energy conversions that occur during photosynthesis and respiration.
B3.1C [9-12] - Recognize the equations for photosynthesis and respiration and identify the reactants and products for both.
B3.1D [9-12] - Explain how living organisms gain and use mass through the processes of photosynthesis and respiration.
B3.1e [9-12] - Write the chemical equation for photosynthesis and cellular respiration and explain in words what they mean.
B3.1f [9-12] - Summarize the process of photosynthesis.
B3.2A [9-12] - Identify how energy is stored in an ecosystem.
B3.2B [9-12] - Describe energy transfer through an ecosystem, accounting for energy lost to the environment as heat.
B3.2C [9-12] - Draw the flow of energy through an ecosystem. Predict changes in the food web when one or more organisms are removed.
B3.3A [9-12] - Use a food web to identify and distinguish producers, consumers, and decomposers and explain the transfer of energy through trophic levels.
B3.3b [9-12] - Describe environmental processes (e.g., the carbon and nitrogen cycles) and their role in processing matter crucial for sustaining life.

B3.4A [9-12] - Describe ecosystem stability. Understand that if a disaster such as flood or fire occurs, the damaged ecosystem is likely to recover in stages of succession that eventually result in a system similar to the original one.
B3.4B [9-12] - Recognize and describe that a great diversity of species increases the chance that at least some living organisms will survive in the face of cataclysmic changes in the environment.
B3.4C [9-12] - Examine the negative impact of human activities.
B3.4d [9-12] - Describe the greenhouse effect and list possible causes.
B3.4e [9-12] - List the possible causes and consequences of global warming.
B3.5A [9-12] - Graph changes in population growth, given a data table.
B3.5B [9-12] - Explain the influences that affect population growth.
B3.5C [9-12] - Predict the consequences of an invading organism on the survival of other organisms.
B3.5d [9-12] - Describe different reproductive strategies employed by various organisms and explain their advantages and disadvantages.
B3.5e [9-12] - Recognize that and describe how the physical or chemical environment may influence the rate, extent, and nature of population dynamics within ecosystems.
B3.5f [9-12] - Graph an example of exponential growth. Then show the population leveling off at the carrying capacity of the environment.
B3.r5g [9-12] - Diagram and describe the stages of the life cycle for a human disease-causing organism. (recommended)
L4.p1A [9-12] - Compare and contrast the differences between sexual and asexual reproduction. (prerequisite)
L4.p1B [9-12] - Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of sexual vs. asexual reproduction. (prerequisite)

L4.p2A [9-12] - Explain that the traits of an individual are influenced by both the environment and the genetics of the individual. Acquired traits are not inherited; only genetic traits are inherited. (prerequisite)
B4.1A [9-12] - Draw and label a homologous chromosome pair with heterozygous alleles highlighting a particular gene location.

B4.1B [9-12] - Explain that the information passed from parents to offspring is transmitted by means of genes that are coded in DNA molecules. These genes contain the information for the production of proteins.
B4.1c [9-12] - Differentiate between dominant, recessive, codominant, polygenic, and sex-linked traits.
B4.1d [9-12] - Explain the genetic basis for Mendel's laws of segregation and independent assortment.
B4.1e [9-12] - Determine the genotype and phenotype of monohybrid crosses using a Punnett Square.

B4.2A [9-12] - Show that when mutations occur in sex cells, they can be passed on to offspring (inherited mutations), but if they occur in other cells, they can be passed on to descendant cells only (noninherited mutations).
B4.2B [9-12] - Recognize that every species has its own characteristic DNA sequence.
B4.2C [9-12] - Describe the structure and function of DNA.
B4.2D [9-12] - Predict the consequences that changes in the DNA composition of particular genes may have on an organism (e.g., sickle cell anemia, other).
B4.2E [9-12] - Propose possible effects (on the genes) of exposing an organism to radiation and toxic chemicals.
B4.2x [9-12] - DNA, RNA, and Protein Synthesis
B4.2f [9-12] - Demonstrate how the genetic information in DNA molecules provides instructions for assembling protein molecules and that this is virtually the same mechanism for all life forms.
B4.2g [9-12] - Describe the processes of replication, transcription, and translation and how they relate to each other in molecular biology.
B4.2h [9-12] - Recognize that genetic engineering techniques provide great potential and responsibilities.
B4.r2i [9-12] - Explain how recombinant DNA technology allows scientists to analyze the structure and function of genes. (recommended)
B4.3 [9-12] - Cell Division – Mitosis and Meiosis

B4.3A [9-12] - Compare and contrast the processes of cell division (mitosis and meiosis), particularly as those processes relate to production of new cells and to passing on genetic information between generations.
B4.3B [9-12] - Explain why only mutations occurring in gametes (sex cells) can be passed on to offspring.
B4.3C [9-12] - Explain how it might be possible to identify genetic defects from just a karyotype of a few cells.
B4.3d [9-12] - Explain that the sorting and recombination of genes in sexual reproduction result in a great variety of possible gene combinations from the offspring of two parents.
B4.3e [9-12] - Recognize that genetic variation can occur from such processes as crossing over, jumping genes, and deletion and duplication of genes.
B4.3f [9-12] - Predict how mutations may be transferred to progeny.
B4.3g [9-12] - Explain that cellular differentiation results from gene expression and/or environmental influence (e.g., metamorphosis, nutrition).

B4.4a [9-12] - Describe how inserting, deleting, or substituting DNA segments can alter a gene. Recognize that an altered gene may be passed on to every cell that develops from it and that the resulting features may help, harm, or have little or no effect on the offspring's success in its environment.

B4.4b [9-12] - Explain that gene mutation in a cell can result in uncontrolled cell division called cancer. Also know that exposure of cells to certain chemicals and radiation increases mutations and thus increases the chance of cancer.
B4.4c [9-12] - Explain how mutations in the DNA sequence of a gene may be silent or result in phenotypic change in an organism and in its offspring.
B4.r5a [9-12] - Explain how recombinant DNA technology allows scientists to analyze the structure and function of genes. (recommended)
B4.r5b [9-12] - Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of human manipulation of DNA. (recommended)
L5.p1A [9-12] - Define a species and give examples. (prerequisite)
L5.p1B [9-12] - Define a population and identify local populations. (prerequisite)
L5.p1C [9-12] - Explain how extinction removes genes from the gene pool. (prerequisite)
L5.p1D [9-12] - Explain the importance of the fossil record. (prerequisite)

L5.p2A [9-12] - Explain, with examples, that ecology studies the varieties and interactions of living things across space while evolution studies the varieties and interactions of living things across time. (prerequisite)
B5.1A [9-12] - Summarize the major concepts of natural selection (differential survival and reproduction of chance inherited variants, depending on environmental conditions).
B5.1B [9-12] - Describe how natural selection provides a mechanism for evolution.

B5.1c [9-12] - Summarize the relationships between present-day organisms and those that inhabited the Earth in the past (e.g., use fossil record, embryonic stages, homologous structures, chemical basis).
B5.1d [9-12] - Explain how a new species or variety originates through the evolutionary process of natural selection.

B5.1e [9-12] - Explain how natural selection leads to organisms that are well suited for the environment (differential survival and reproduction of chance inherited variants, depending upon environmental conditions).
B5.1f [9-12] - Explain, using examples, how the fossil record, comparative anatomy, and other evidence supports the theory of evolution.
B5.1g [9-12] - Illustrate how genetic variation is preserved or eliminated from a population through natural selection (evolution) resulting in biodiversity.
B5.2a [9-12] - Describe species as reproductively distinct groups of organisms that can be classified based on morphological, behavioral, and molecular similarities.
B5.2b [9-12] - Explain that the degree of kinship between organisms or species can be estimated from the similarity of their DNA and protein sequences.
B5.2c [9-12] - Trace the relationship between environmental changes and changes in the gene pool, such as genetic drift and isolation of subpopulations.
B5.r2d [9-12] - Interpret a cladogram or phylogenetic tree showing evolutionary relationships among organisms. (recommended)

B5.3A [9-12] - Explain how natural selection acts on individuals, but it is populations that evolve. Relate genetic mutations and genetic variety produced by sexual reproduction to diversity within a given population.
B5.3B [9-12] - Describe the role of geographic isolation in speciation.
B4.3C [9-12] - Give examples of ways in which genetic variation and environmental factors are causes of evolution and the diversity of organisms.
B5.3d [9-12] - Explain how evolution through natural selection can result in changes in biodiversity.
B5.3e [9-12] - Explain how changes at the gene level are the foundation for changes in populations and eventually the formation of new species.
B5.3f [9-12] - Demonstrate and explain how biotechnology can improve a population and species.
MI - Chemistry High School Content Expectations
C1 [9-12] - Inquiry, Reflection, and Social Implications
C1.1A [9-12] - Generate new questions that can be investigated in the laboratory or field.

C1.1B [9-12] - Evaluate the uncertainties or validity of scientific conclusions using an understanding of sources of measurement error, the challenges of controlling variables, accuracy of data analysis, logic of argument, logic of experimental design, and/or the dependence on underlying assumptions.

C1.1C [9-12] - Conduct scientific investigations using appropriate tools and techniques (e.g., selecting an instrument that measures the desired quantity—length, volume, weight, time interval, temperature—with the appropriate level of precision).
C1.1D [9-12] - Identify patterns in data and relate them to theoretical models.
C1.1E [9-12] - Describe a reason for a given conclusion using evidence from an investigation.
C1.1f [9-12] - Predict what would happen if the variables, methods, or timing of an investigation were changed.
C1.1g [9-12] - Based on empirical evidence, explain and critique the reasoning used to draw a scientific conclusion or explanation
C1.1h [9-12] - Design and conduct a systematic scientific investigation that tests a hypothesis. Draw conclusions from data presented in charts or tables.
C1.1i [9-12] - Distinguish between scientific explanations that are regarded as current scientific consensus and the emerging questions that active researchers investigate.
C1.2 [9-12] - Scientific Reflection and Social Implications
C1.2A [9-12] - Critique whether or not specific questions can be answered through scientific investigations.
C1.2B [9-12] - Identify and critique arguments about personal or societal issues based on scientific evidence.
C1.2C [9-12] - Develop an understanding of a scientific concept by accessing information from multiple sources. Evaluate the scientific accuracy and significance of the information.
C1.2D [9-12] - Evaluate scientific explanations in a peer review process or discussion format.
C1.2E [9-12] - Evaluate the future career and occupational prospects of science fields.
C1.2f [9-12] - Critique solutions to problems, given criteria and scientific constraints.
C1.2g [9-12] - Identify scientific tradeoffs in design decisions and choose among alternative solutions.
C1.2h [9-12] - Describe the distinctions between scientific theories, laws, hypotheses, and observations.
C1.2i [9-12] - Explain the progression of ideas and explanations that lead to science theories that are part of the current scientific consensus or core knowledge.
C1.2j [9-12] - Apply science principles or scientific data to anticipate effects of technological design decisions.
C1.2k [9-12] - Analyze how science and society interact from a historical, political, economic, or social perspective.
P2.p1A [9-12] - Describe energy changes associated with changes of state in terms of the arrangement and order of the atoms (molecules) in each state. (prerequisite)

P2.p1B [9-12] - Use the positions and arrangements of atoms and molecules in solid, liquid, and gas state to explain the need for an input of energy for melting and boiling and a release of energy in condensation and freezing. (prerequisite)
C2.1a [9-12] - Explain the changes in potential energy (due to electrostatic interactions) as a chemical bond forms and use this to explain why bond breaking always requires energy.
C2.1b [9-12] - Describe energy changes associated with chemical reactions in terms of bonds broken and formed (including intermolecular forces).
C2.1c [9-12] - Compare qualitatively the energy changes associated with melting various types of solids in terms of the types of forces between the particles in the solid.
C2.2A [9-12] - Describe conduction in terms of molecules bumping into each other to transfer energy. Explain why there is better conduction in solids and liquids than gases.
C2.2B [9-12] - Describe the various states of matter in terms of the motion and arrangement of the molecules (atoms) making up the substance.
C2.2c [9-12] - Explain changes in pressure, volume, and temperature for gases using the kinetic molecular model.
C2.2d [9-12] - Explain convection and the difference in transfer of thermal energy for solids, liquids, and gases using evidence that molecules are in constant motion.
C2.2e [9-12] - Compare the entropy of solids, liquids, and gases.
C2.2f [9-12] - Compare the average kinetic energy of the molecules in a metal object and a wood object at room temperature.
C2.3a [9-12] - Explain how the rate of a given chemical reaction is dependent on the temperature and the activation energy.
C2.3b [9-12] - Draw and analyze a diagram to show the activation energy for an exothermic reaction that is very slow at room temperature.
C2.4a [9-12] - Describe energy changes in flame tests of common elements in terms of the (characteristic) electron transitions.
C2.4b [9-12] - Contrast the mechanism of energy changes and the appearance of absorption and emission spectra.
C2.4c [9-12] - Explain why an atom can absorb only certain wavelengths of light.
C2.4d [9-12] - Compare various wavelengths of light (visible and nonvisible) in terms of frequency and relative energy.
C2.5a [9-12] - Determine the age of materials using the ratio of stable and unstable isotopes of a particular type.
C2.r5b [9-12] - Illustrate how elements can change in nuclear reactions using balanced equations. (recommended)
C2.r5c [9-12] - Describe the potential energy changes as two protons approach each other. (recommended)
C2.r5d [9-12] - Describe how and where all the elements on earth were formed. (recommended)

P3.p1A [9-12] - Explain that the amount of energy necessary to heat a substance will be the same as the amount of energy released when the substance is cooled to the original temperature. (prerequisite)
C3.1a [9-12] - Calculate the ΔH for a given reaction using Hess's Law.
C3.1b [9-12] - Draw enthalpy diagrams for exothermic and endothermic reactions.
C3.1c [9-12] - Calculate the ΔH for a chemical reaction using simple coffee cup calorimetry.
C3.1d [9-12] - Calculate the amount of heat produced for a given mass of reactant from a balanced chemical equation.
P3.p2A [9-12] - Trace (or diagram) energy transfers involving various types of energy including nuclear, chemical, electrical, sound, and light. (prerequisite)
C3.2a [9-12] - Describe the energy changes in photosynthesis and in the combustion of sugar in terms of bond breaking and bond making.
C3.2b [9-12] - Describe the relative strength of single, double, and triple covalent bonds between nitrogen atoms.
C3.3A [9-12] - Describe how heat is conducted in a solid.
C3.3B [9-12] - Describe melting on a molecular level.
C3.3c [9-12] - Explain why it is necessary for a molecule to absorb energy in order to break a chemical bond.
C3.4A [9-12] - Use the terms endothermic and exothermic correctly to describe chemical reactions in the laboratory.
C3.4B [9-12] - Explain why chemical reactions will either release or absorb energy.
C3.4c [9-12] - Write chemical equations including the heat term as a part of equation or using ΔH notation.
C3.4d [9-12] - Draw enthalpy diagrams for reactants and products in endothermic and exothermic reactions.

C3.4e [9-12] - Predict if a chemical reaction is spontaneous given the enthalpy (ΔH) and entropy (ΔS) changes for the reaction using Gibb's Free Energy, ΔG = ΔH - TΔS (Note: mathematical computation of ΔG is not required.)
C3.4f [9-12] - Explain why some endothermic reactions are spontaneous at room temperature.
C3.4g [9-12] - Explain why gases are less soluble in warm water than cold water.
C3.5a [9-12] - Explain why matter is not conserved in nuclear reactions.
P4.p1A [9-12] - For a substance that can exist in all three phases, describe the relative motion of the particles in each of the phases. (prerequisite)
P4.p1B [9-12] - For a substance that can exist in all three phases, make a drawing that shows the arrangement and relative spacing of the particles in each of the phases. (prerequisite)
P4.p1C [9-12] - For a simple compound, present a drawing that shows the number of particles in the system does not change as a result of a phase change. (prerequisite)
P4.p2A [9-12] - Distinguish between an element, compound, or mixture based on drawings or formulae. (prerequisite)
P4.p2B [9-12] - Identify a pure substance (element or compound) based on unique chemical and physical properties. (prerequisite)
P4.p2C [9-12] - Separate mixtures based on the differences in physical properties of the individual components. (prerequisite)
P4.p2D [9-12] - Recognize that the properties of a compound differ from those of its individual elements. (prerequisite)
C4.1a [9-12] - Calculate the percent by weight of each element in a compound based on the compound formula.
C4.1b [9-12] - Calculate the empirical formula of a compound based on the percent by weight of each element in the compound.
C4.1c [9-12] - Use the empirical formula and molecular weight of a compound to determine the molecular formula.
C4.2A [9-12] - Name simple binary compounds using their formulae.
C4.2B [9-12] - Given the name, write the formula of simple binary compounds.
C4.2c [9-12] - Given a formula, name the compound.
C4.2d [9-12] - Given the name, write the formula of ionic and molecular compounds.
C4.2e [9-12] - Given the formula for a simple hydrocarbon, draw and name the isomers.

C4.3A [9-12] - Recognize that substances that are solid at room temperature have stronger attractive forces than liquids at room temperature, which have stronger attractive forces than gases at room temperature.
C4.3B [9-12] - Recognize that solids have a more ordered, regular arrangement of their particles than liquids and that liquids are more ordered than gases.
C4.3c [9-12] - Compare the relative strengths of forces between molecules based on the melting point and boiling point of the substances.
C4.3d [9-12] - Compare the strength of the forces of attraction between molecules of different elements. (For example, at room temperature, chlorine is a gas and iodine is a solid.)
C4.3e [9-12] - Predict whether the forces of attraction in a solid are primarily metallic, covalent, network covalent, or ionic based upon the elements' location on the periodic table.
C4.3f [9-12] - Identify the elements necessary for hydrogen bonding (N, O, F).
C4.3g [9-12] - Given the structural formula of a compound, indicate all the intermolecular forces present (dispersion, dipolar, hydrogen bonding).
C4.3h [9-12] - Explain properties of various solids such as malleability, conductivity, and melting point in terms of the solid's structure and bonding.
C4.3i [9-12] - Explain why ionic solids have higher melting points than covalent solids. (For example, NaF has a melting point of 995°C, while water has a melting point of 0° C.)
C4.4a [9-12] - Explain why at room temperature different compounds can exist in different phases.
C4.4b [9-12] - Identify if a molecule is polar or nonpolar given a structural formula for the compound.
C4.5a [9-12] - Provide macroscopic examples, atomic and molecular explanations, and mathematical representations (graphs and equations) for the pressure-volume relationship in gases.
C4.5b [9-12] - Provide macroscopic examples, atomic and molecular explanations, and mathematical representations (graphs and equations) for the pressure-temperature relationship in gases.
C4.5c [9-12] - Provide macroscopic examples, atomic and molecular explanations, and mathematical representations (graphs and equations) for the temperature-volume relationship in gases.
C4.6a [9-12] - Calculate the number of moles of any compound or element given the mass of the substance.
C4.6b [9-12] - Calculate the number of particles of any compound or element given the mass of the substance.
C4.7a [9-12] - Investigate the difference in the boiling point or freezing point of pure water and a salt solution.
C4.7b [9-12] - Compare the density of pure water to that of a sugar solution.
C4.8A [9-12] - Identify the location, relative mass, and charge for electrons, protons, and neutrons.
C4.8B [9-12] - Describe the atom as mostly empty space with an extremely small, dense nucleus consisting of the protons and neutrons and an electron cloud surrounding the nucleus.
C4.8C [9-12] - Recognize that protons repel each other and that a strong force needs to be present to keep the nucleus intact.
C4.8D [9-12] - Give the number of electrons and protons present if the fluoride ion has a -1 charge.
C4.8e [9-12] - Write the complete electron configuration of elements in the first four rows of the periodic table.
C4.8f [9-12] - Write kernel structures for main group elements.
C4.8g [9-12] - Predict oxidation states and bonding capacity for main group elements using their electron structure.
C4.8h [9-12] - Describe the shape and orientation of s and p orbitals.
C4.8i [9-12] - Describe the fact that the electron location cannot be exactly determined at any given time.
C4.9A [9-12] - Identify elements with similar chemical and physical properties using the periodic table.
C4.9b [9-12] - Identify metals, non-metals, and metalloids using the periodic table.
C4.9c [9-12] - Predict general trends in atomic radius, first ionization energy, and electonegativity of the elements using the periodic table.
C4.10 [9-12] - Neutral Atoms, Ions, and Isotopes
C4.10A [9-12] - List the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons for any given ion or isotope.
C4.10B [9-12] - Recognize that an element always contains the same number of protons.
C4.10c [9-12] - Calculate the average atomic mass of an element given the percent abundance and mass of the individual isotopes.
C4.10d [9-12] - Predict which isotope will have the greatest abundance given the possible isotopes for an element and the average atomic mass in the periodic table.
C4.10e [9-12] - Write the symbol for an isotope, A, where Z is the atomic number, A is the mass number, and X is the symbol for the element.
P5.p1A [9-12] - Draw a picture of the particles of an element or compound as a solid, liquid, and gas. (prerequisite)
C5.r1a [9-12] - Predict how the rate of a chemical reaction will be influenced by changes in concentration, and temperature, pressure. (recommended)
C5.r1b [9-12] - Explain how the rate of a reaction will depend on concentration, temperature, pressure, and nature of reactant. (recommended)
C5.2A [9-12] - Balance simple chemical equations applying the conservation of matter.
C5.2B [9-12] - Distinguish between chemical and physical changes in terms of the properties of the reactants and products.
C5.2C [9-12] - Draw pictures to distinguish the relationships between atoms in physical and chemical changes.
C5.2d [9-12] - Calculate the mass of a particular compound formed from the masses of starting materials.
C5.2e [9-12] - Identify the limiting reagent when given the masses of more than one reactant.
C5.2f [9-12] - Predict volumes of product gases using initial volumes of gases at the same temperature and pressure.
C5.2g [9-12] - Calculate the number of atoms present in a given mass of element.
C5.3a [9-12] - Describe equilibrium shifts in a chemical system caused by changing conditions (Le Chatelier's Principle).
C5.3b [9-12] - Predict shifts in a chemical system caused by changing conditions (Le Chatelier's Principle).
C5.3c [9-12] - Predict the extent reactants are converted to products using the value of the equilibrium constant.
C5.4A [9-12] - Compare the energy required to raise the temperature of one gram of aluminum and one gram of water the same number of degrees.
C5.4B [9-12] - Measure, plot, and interpret the graph of the temperature versus time of an ice-water mixture, under slow heating, through melting and boiling.
C5.4c [9-12] - Explain why both the melting point and boiling points for water are significantly higher than other small molecules of comparable mass (e.g., ammonia and methane).
C5.4d [9-12] - Explain why freezing is an exothermic change of state.
C5.4e [9-12] - Compare the melting point of covalent compounds based on the strength of IMFs (intermolecular forces).
C5.5A [9-12] - Predict if the bonding between two atoms of different elements will be primarily ionic or covalent.
C5.4B [9-12] - Predict the formula for binary compounds of main group elements.
C5.5c [9-12] - Draw Lewis structures for simple compounds.
C5.5d [9-12] - Compare the relative melting point, electrical and thermal conductivity and hardness for ionic, metallic, and covalent compounds.
C5.5e [9-12] - Relate the melting point, hardness, and electrical and thermal conductivity of a substance to its structure.
C5.6a [9-12] - Balance half-reactions and describe them as oxidations or reductions.
C5.6c [9-12] - Explain oxidation occurring when two different metals are in contact.
C5.6d [9-12] - Calculate the voltage for spontaneous redox reactions from the standard reduction potentials.
C5.6e [9-12] - Identify the reactions occurring at the anode and cathode in an electrochemical cell.
C5.7A [9-12] - Recognize formulas for common inorganic acids, carboxylic acids, and bases formed from families I and II.
C5.7B [9-12] - Predict products of an acid-base neutralization.
C5.7C [9-12] - Describe tests that can be used to distinguish an acid from a base.
C5.7D [9-12] - Classify various solutions as acidic or basic, given their pH.
C5.7E [9-12] - Explain why lakes with limestone or calcium carbonate experience less adverse effects from acid rain than lakes with granite beds.
C5.7f [9-12] - Write balanced chemical equations for reactions between acids and bases and perform calculations with balanced equations.
C5.7g [9-12] - Calculate the pH from the hydronium ion or hydroxide ion concentration.
C5.7h [9-12] - Explain why sulfur oxides and nitrogen oxides contribute to acid rain.
C5.r7i [9-12] - Identify the Brønsted-Lowry conjugate acid-base pairs in an equation. (recommended)
C5.8A [9-12] - Draw structural formulas for up to ten carbon chains of simple hydrocarbons.
C5.8B [9-12] - Draw isomers for simple hydrocarbons.
C5.8C [9-12] - Recognize that proteins, starches, and other large biological molecules are polymers.
MI - Earth Science High School Content Expectations
E1 [9-12] - Inquiry, Reflection, and Social Implications
E1.1A [9-12] - Generate new questions that can be investigated in the laboratory or field.

E1.1B [9-12] - Evaluate the uncertainties or validity of scientific conclusions using an understanding of sources of measurement error, the challenges of controlling variables, accuracy of data analysis, logic of argument, logic of experimental design, and/or the dependence on underlying assumptions.

E1.1C [9-12] - Conduct scientific investigations using appropriate tools and techniques (e.g., selecting an instrument that measures the desired quantity—length, volume, weight, time interval, temperature—with the appropriate level of precision).
E1.1D [9-12] - Identify patterns in data and relate them to theoretical models.
E1.1E [9-12] - Describe a reason for a given conclusion using evidence from an investigation.
E1.1f [9-12] - Predict what would happen if the variables, methods, or timing of an investigation were changed.
E1.1g [9-12] - Based on empirical evidence, explain and critique the reasoning used to draw a scientific conclusion or explanation.
E1.1h [9-12] - Design and conduct a systematic scientific investigation that tests a hypothesis. Draw conclusions from data presented in charts or tables.
E1.1i [9-12] - Distinguish between scientific explanations that are regarded as current scientific consensus and the emerging questions that active researchers investigate.
E1.2 [9-12] - Scientific Reflection and Social Implications
E1.2A [9-12] - Critique whether or not specific questions can be answered through scientific investigations.
E1.2B [9-12] - Identify and critique arguments about personal or societal issues based on scientific evidence.
E1.2C [9-12] - Develop an understanding of a scientific concept by accessing information from multiple sources. Evaluate the scientific accuracy and significance of the information.
E1.2D [9-12] - Evaluate scientific explanations in a peer review process or discussion format.
E1.2E [9-12] - Evaluate the future career and occupational prospects of science fields.
E1.2f [9-12] - Critique solutions to problems, given criteria and scientific constraints.
E1.2g [9-12] - Identify scientific tradeoffs in design decisions and choose among alternative solutions.
E1.2h [9-12] - Describe the distinctions between scientific theories, laws, hypotheses, and observations.
E1.2i [9-12] - Explain the progression of ideas and explanations that lead to science theories that are part of the current scientific consensus or core knowledge.
E1.2j [9-12] - Apply science principles or scientific data to anticipate effects of technological design decisions.
E1.2k [9-12] - Analyze how science and society interact from a historical, political, economic, or social perspective.
E2.1A [9-12] - Explain why the Earth is essentially a closed system in terms of matter.
E2.1B [9-12] - Analyze the interactions between the major systems (geosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere) that make up the Earth.
E2.1C [9-12] - Explain, using specific examples, how a change in one system affects other Earth systems.
E2.2A [9-12] - Describe the Earth's principal sources of internal and external energy (e.g., radioactive decay, gravity, solar energy).
E2.2B [9-12] - Identify differences in the origin and use of renewable (e.g., solar, wind, water, biomass) and nonrenewable (e.g., fossil fuels, nuclear [U-235]) sources of energy.
E2.2C [9-12] - Describe natural processes in which heat transfer in the Earth occurs by conduction, convection, and radiation.
E2.2D [9-12] - Identify the main sources of energy to the climate system.
E2.2e [9-12] - Explain how energy changes form through Earth systems.
E2.2f [9-12] - Explain how elements exist in different compounds and states as they move from one reservoir to another.

E2.3A [9-12] - Explain how carbon exists in different forms such as limestone (rock), carbon dioxide (gas), carbonic acid (water), and animals (life) within Earth systems and how those forms can be beneficial or harmful to humans.

E2.3b [9-12] - Explain why small amounts of some chemical forms may be beneficial for life but are poisonous in large quantities (e.g., dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico, Lake Nyos in Africa, fluoride in drinking water).
E2.3c [9-12] - Explain how the nitrogen cycle is part of the Earth system.
E2.3d [9-12] - Explain how carbon moves through the Earth system (including the geosphere) and how it may benefit (e.g., improve soils for agriculture) or harm (e.g., act as a pollutant) society.
E2.4 [9-12] - Resources and Human Impacts on Earth Systems
E2.4A [9-12] - Describe renewable and nonrenewable sources of energy for human consumption (electricity, fuels), compare their effects on the environment, and include overall costs and benefits.

E2.4B [9-12] - Explain how the impact of human activities on the environment (e.g., deforestation, air pollution, coral reef destruction) can be understood through the analysis of interactions between the four Earth systems.
E2.4c [9-12] - Explain ozone depletion in the stratosphere and methods to slow human activities to reduce ozone depletion.
E2.4d [9-12] - Describe the life cycle of a product, including the resources, production, packaging, transportation, disposal, and pollution.
E3.p1A [9-12] - Explain the origin of Michigan landforms. Describe and identify surface features using maps and satellite images. (prerequisite)
E3.p1B [9-12] - Explain how physical and chemical weathering leads to erosion and the formation of soils and sediments. (prerequisite)
E3.p1C [9-12] - Describe how coastal features are formed by wave erosion and deposition. (prerequisite)
E3.p2A [9-12] - Identify common rock-forming minerals (quartz, feldspar, biotite, calcite, hornblende). (prerequisite)

E3.p2B [9-12] - Identify common igneous (granite, basalt, andesite, obsidian, pumice), metamorphic (schist, gneiss, marble, slate, quartzite), and sedimentary (sandstone, limestone, shale, conglomerate) rocks and describe the processes that change one kind of rock to another. (prerequisite)
E3.p3A [9-12] - Describe geologic, paleontologic, and paleoclimatalogic evidence that indicates Africa and South America were once part of a single continent.

E3.p3B [9-12] - Describe the three types of plate boundaries (divergent, convergent, and transform) and geographic features associated with them (e.g., continental rifts and mid-ocean ridges, volcanic and island arcs, deep-sea trenches, transform faults).
E3.p3C [9-12] - Describe the three major types of volcanoes (shield volcano, stratovolcano, and cinder cones) and their relationship to the Ring of Fire.
E3.1A [9-12] - Discriminate between igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks and describe the processes that change one kind of rock into another.
E3.1B [9-12] - Explain the relationship between the rock cycle and plate tectonics theory in regard to the origins of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks.
E3.1c [9-12] - Explain how the size and shape of grains in a sedimentary rock indicate the environment of formation (including climate) and deposition.
E3.1d [9-12] - Explain how the crystal sizes of igneous rocks indicate the rate of cooling and whether the rock is extrusive or intrusive.
E3.1e [9-12] - Explain how the texture (foliated, nonfoliated) of metamorphic rock can indicate whether it has experienced regional or contact metamorphism.
E3.2A [9-12] - Describe the interior of the Earth (in terms of crust, mantle, and inner and outer cores) and where the magnetic field of the Earth is generated.
E3.2B [9-12] - Explain how scientists infer that the Earth has interior layers with discernable properties using patterns of primary (P) and secondary (S) seismic wave arrivals.
E3.2C [9-12] - Describe the differences between oceanic and continental crust (including density, age, composition).
E3.2d [9-12] - Explain the uncertainties associated with models of the interior of the Earth and how these models are validated.

E3.3A [9-12] - Explain how plate tectonics accounts for the features and processes (sea floor spreading, mid-ocean ridges, subduction zones, earthquakes and volcanoes, mountain ranges) that occur on or near the Earth's surface.

E3.3B [9-12] - Explain why tectonic plates move using the concept of heat flowing through mantle convection, coupled with the cooling and sinking of aging ocean plates that result from their increased density.
E3.3C [9-12] - Describe the motion history of geologic features (e.g., plates, Hawaii) using equations relating rate, time, and distance.
E3.3d [9-12] - Distinguish plate boundaries by the pattern of depth and magnitude of earthquakes.
E3.r3e [9-12] - Predict the temperature distribution in the lithosphere as a function of distance from the mid-ocean ridge and how it relates to ocean depth. (recommended)
E3.r3f [9-12] - Describe how the direction and rate of movement for the North American plate has affected the local climate over the last 600 million years. (recommended)
E3.4A [9-12] - Use the distribution of earthquakes and volcanoes to locate and determine the types of plate boundaries.
E3.4B [9-12] - Describe how the sizes of earthquakes and volcanoes are measured or characterized.
E3.4C [9-12] - Describe the effects of earthquakes and volcanic eruptions on humans.
E3.4d [9-12] - Explain how the chemical composition of magmas relates to plate tectonics and affects the geometry, structure, and explosivity of volcanoes.
E3.4e [9-12] - Explain how volcanoes change the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and other Earth systems.
E3.4f [9-12] - Explain why fences are offset after an earthquake, using the elastic rebound theory.
E4.p1A [9-12] - Describe that the water cycle includes evaporation, transpiration, condensation, precipitation, infiltration, surface runoff, groundwater, and absorption. (prerequisite)
E4.p1B [9-12] - Analyze the flow of water between the elements of a watershed, including surface features (lakes, streams, rivers, wetlands) and groundwater. (prerequisite)

E4.p1C [9-12] - Describe the river and stream types, features, and process including cycles of flooding, erosion, and deposition as they occur naturally and as they are impacted by land use decisions. (prerequisite)
E4.p1D [9-12] - Explain the types, process, and beneficial functions of wetlands.
E4.p2A [9-12] - Describe the composition and layers of the atmosphere. (prerequisite)
E4.p2B [9-12] - Describe the difference between weather and climate. (prerequisite)
E4.p2C [9-12] - Explain the differences between fog and dew formation and cloud formation. (prerequisite)
E4.p2D [9-12] - Describe relative humidity in terms of the moisture content of the air and the moisture capacity of the air and how these depend on the temperature. (prerequisite)
E4.p2E [9-12] - Describe conditions associated with frontal boundaries (cold, warm, stationary, and occluded). (prerequisite)
E4.p2F [9-12] - Describe the characteristics and movement across North America of the major air masses and the jet stream. (prerequisite)
E4.p2G [9-12] - Interpret a weather map and describe present weather conditions and predict changes in weather over 24 hours. (prerequisite)
E4.p2H [9-12] - Explain the primary causes of seasons. (prerequisite)

E4.p2I [9-12] - Identify major global wind belts (trade winds, prevailing westerlies, and polar easterlies) and that their vertical components control the global distribution of rainforests and deserts. (prerequisite)
E4.p3A [9-12] - Describe how glaciers have affected the Michigan landscape and how the resulting landforms impact our state economy. (prerequisite)
E4.p3B [9-12] - Explain what happens to the lithosphere when an ice sheet is removed. (prerequisite)
E4.p3C [9-12] - Explain the formation of the Great Lakes. (prerequisite)

E4.1A [9-12] - Compare and contrast surface water systems (lakes, rivers, streams, wetlands) and groundwater in regard to their relative sizes as Earth's freshwater reservoirs and the dynamics of water movement (inputs and outputs, residence times, sustainability).

E4.1B [9-12] - Explain the features and processes of groundwater systems and how the sustainability of North American aquifers has changed in recent history (e.g., the past 100 years) qualitatively using the concepts of recharge, residence time, inputs, and outputs.
E4.1C [9-12] - Explain how water quality in both groundwater and surface systems is impacted by land use decisions.

E4.2A [9-12] - Describe the major causes for the ocean's surface and deep water currents, including the prevailing winds, the Coriolis effect, unequal heating of the earth, changes in water temperature and salinity in high latitudes, and basin shape.

E4.2B [9-12] - Explain how interactions between the oceans and the atmosphere influence global and regional climate. Include the major concepts of heat transfer by ocean currents, thermohaline circulation, boundary currents, evaporation, precipitation, climatic zones, and the ocean as a major CO<sub>2</sub> reservoir.
E4.2c [9-12] - Explain the dynamics (including ocean-atmosphere interactions) of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and its effect on continental climates.
E4.2d [9-12] - Identify factors affecting seawater density and salinity and describe how density affects oceanic layering and currents.
E4.2e [9-12] - Explain the differences between maritime and continental climates with regard to oceanic currents.
E4.2f [9-12] - Explain how the Coriolis effect controls oceanic circulation.
E4.r2g [9-12] - Explain how El Niño affects economies (e.g., in South America). (recommended)
E4.3A [9-12] - Describe the various conditions of formation associated with severe weather (thunderstorms, tornadoes, hurricanes, floods, waves, and drought).
E4.3B [9-12] - Describe the damage resulting from, and the social impact of thunderstorms, tornadoes, hurricanes, and floods.
E4.3C [9-12] - Describe severe weather and flood safety and mitigation.
E4.3D [9-12] - Describe the seasonal variations in severe weather.
E4.3E [9-12] - Describe conditions associated with frontal boundaries that result in severe weather (thunderstorms, tornadoes, and hurricanes).
E4.3F [9-12] - Describe how mountains, frontal wedging (including dry lines), convection, and convergence form clouds and precipitation.
E4.3g [9-12] - Explain the process of adiabatic cooling and adiabatic temperature changes to the formation of clouds.
E5 [9-12] - The Earth in Space and Time
E5.p1A [9-12] - Describe the motions of various celestial bodies and some effects of those motions. (prerequisite)
E5.p1B [9-12] - Explain the primary cause of seasons. (prerequisite)
E5.p1C [9-12] - Explain how a light year can be used as a distance unit. (prerequisite)
E5.p1D [9-12] - Describe the position and motion of our solar system in our galaxy. (prerequisite)
E5.1A [9-12] - Describe the position and motion of our solar system in our galaxy and the overall scale, structure, and age of the universe.
E5.1b [9-12] - Describe how the Big Bang theory accounts for the formation of the universe.
E5.1c [9-12] - Explain how observations of the cosmic microwave background have helped determine the age of the universe.
E5.1d [9-12] - Differentiate between the cosmological and Doppler red shift.
E5.2A [9-12] - Identify patterns in solar activities (sunspot cycle, solar flares, solar wind).
E5.2B [9-12] - Relate events on the Sun to phenomena such as auroras, disruption of radio and satellite communications, and power grid disturbances.
E5.2C [9-12] - Describe how nuclear fusion produces energy in the Sun.
E5.2D [9-12] - Describe how nuclear fusion and other processes in stars have led to the formation of all the other chemical elements.
E5.2e [9-12] - Explain how the Hertzsprung-Russell (H-R) diagram can be used to deduce other parameters (distance).
E5.2f [9-12] - Explain how you can infer the temperature, life span, and mass of a star from its color. Use the H-R diagram to explain the life cycles of stars.
E5.2g [9-12] - Explain how the balance between fusion and gravity controls the evolution of a star (equilibrium).
E5.2h [9-12] - Compare the evolution paths of low-, moderate-, and high-mass stars using the H-R diagram.
E5.3 [9-12] - Earth History and Geologic Time
E5.3A [9-12] - Explain how the solar system formed from a nebula of dust and gas in a spiral arm of the Milky Way Galaxy about 4.6 Ga (billion years ago).
E5.3B [9-12] - Describe the process of radioactive decay and explain how radioactive elements are used to date the rocks that contain them.

E5.3C [9-12] - Relate major events in the history of the Earth to the geologic time scale, including formation of the Earth, formation of an oxygen atmosphere, rise of life, Cretaceous-Tertiary (K-T) and Permian extinctions, and Pleistocene ice age.
E5.3D [9-12] - Describe how index fossils can be used to determine time sequence.

E5.3e [9-12] - Determine the approximate age of a sample, when given the half-life of a radioactive substance (in graph or tabular form) along with the ratio of daughter to parent substances present in the sample.
E5.3f [9-12] - Explain why C-14 can be used to date a 40,000 year old tree, but U-Pb cannot.
E5.3g [9-12] - Identify a sequence of geologic events using relative-age dating principles.
E5.4A [9-12] - Explain the natural mechanism of the greenhouse effect, including comparisons of the major greenhouse gases (water vapor, carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, and ozone).
E5.4B [9-12] - Describe natural mechanisms that could result in significant changes in climate (e.g., major volcanic eruptions, changes in sunlight received by the earth, and meteorite impacts).
E5.4C [9-12] - Analyze the empirical relationship between the emissions of carbon dioxide, atmospheric carbon dioxide levels, and the average global temperature over the past 150 years.

E5.4D [9-12] - Based on evidence of observable changes in recent history and climate change models, explain the consequences of warmer oceans (including the results of increased evaporation, shoreline and estuarine impacts, oceanic algae growth, and coral bleaching) and changing climatic zones (including the adaptive capacity of the biosphere).

E5.4e [9-12] - Based on evidence from historical climate research (e.g. fossils, varves, ice core data) and climate change models, explain how the current melting of polar ice caps can impact the climatic system .
E5.4f [9-12] - Describe geologic evidence that implies climates were significantly colder at times in the geologic record (e.g., geomorphology, striations, and fossils).

E5.4g [9-12] - Compare and contrast the heat-trapping mechanisms of the major greenhouse gases resulting from emissions (carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, fluorocarbons) as well as their abundance and heat- trapping capacity.
E5.r4h [9-12] - Use oxygen isotope data to estimate paleotemperature. (recommended)
E5.r4i [9-12] - Explain the causes of short-term climate changes such as catastrophic volcanic eruptions and impact of solar system objects. (recommended)
E5.r4j [9-12] - Predict the global temperature increase by 2100, given data on the annual trends of CO<sub>2</sub> concentration increase. (recommended)
MI - High School Science Essential Content Standards and Expectations
E1 [9-12] - Inquiry, Reflection, and Social Implications
E1.1A [9-12] - Generate new questions that can be investigated in the laboratory or field.

E1.1B [9-12] - Evaluate the uncertainties or validity of scientific conclusions using an understanding of sources of measurement error, the challenges of controlling variables, accuracy of data analysis, logic of argument, logic of experimental design, and/or the dependence on underlying assumptions.
