[0,3,5] - K-7 Standard P.FM: Develop an understanding that the position and/or motion of an object is relative to a point of reference. Understand forces affect the motion and speed of an object and that the net force on an object is the total of all of the forces acting on it. Understand the Earth pulls down on objects with a force called gravity. Develop an understanding that some forces are in direct contact with objects, while other forces are not in direct contact with objects.

P.FM.E.1 [K] - Position- A position of an object can be described by locating the object relative to other objects or a background. The description of the motion of an object from one observer's view may be different from that reported from a different observer's view.
P.FM.00.11 [K] - Compare the position of an object (for example: above, below, in front of, behind, on) in relation to other objects around it.
P.FM.00.12 [K] - Describe the motion of an object (for example: away from or closer to) from different observers' views.
P.FM.E.2 [0,3] - Gravity- Earth pulls down on all objects with a force called gravity. With very few exceptions, objects fall to the ground no matter where the object is on the Earth.
P.FM.00.21 [K] - Observe how objects fall toward the earth.
P.FM.03.22 [3] - Identify the force that pulls objects towards the Earth.

P.FM.E.3 [0,3] - Force- A force is either a push or a pull. The motion of objects can be changed by forces. The size of the change is related to the size of the force. The change is also related to the weight (mass) of the object on which the force is being exerted. When an object does not move in response to a force, it is because another force is being applied by the environment.
P.FM.00.32 [K] - Observe that objects initially at rest will move in the direction of the push or pull.
P.FM.00.33 [K] - Observe how pushes and pulls can change the speed or direction of moving objects.
P.FM.00.34 [K] - Observe how shape (for example: cone, cylinder, sphere), size, and weight of an object can affect motion.
P.FM.03.35 [3] - Describe how a push or a pull is a force.
P.FM.03.36 [3] - Relate a change in motion of an object to the force that caused the change of motion.
P.FM.03.37 [3] - Demonstrate how the change in motion of an object is related to the strength of the force acting upon the object and to the mass of the object.
P.FM.03.38 [3] - Demonstrate when an object does not move in response to a force, it is because another force is acting on it.
P.FM.E.4 [3] - Speed- An object is in motion when its position is changing. The speed of an object is defined by how far it travels divided by the amount of time it took to travel that far.
P.FM.03.41 [3] - Compare and contrast the motion of objects in terms of direction.
P.FM.03.42 [3] - Identify changes in motion (change direction, speeding up, slowing down).
P.FM.03.43 [3] - Calculate the speed of an object based on the distance it travels divided by the amount of time it took to travel that distance.

P.FM.M.2 [5] - Force Interactions- Some forces between objects act when the objects are in direct contact (touching), such as friction and air resistance, or when they are not in direct contact (not touching), such as magnetic force, electrical force, and gravitational force.
P.FM.05.21 [5] - Distinguish between contact forces and non-contact forces.
P.FM.05.22 [5] - Demonstrate contact and non-contact forces to change the motion of an object.

P.FM.M.3 [5] - Force- Forces have a magnitude and direction. Forces can be added. The net force on an object is the sum of all of the forces acting on the object. The speed and/or direction of motion of an object changes when a non-zero net force is applied to it. A balanced force on an object does not change the motion of the object (the object either remains at rest or continues to move at a constant speed in a straight line).
P.FM.05.31 [5] - Describe what happens when two forces act on an object in the same or opposing directions.
P.FM.05.32 [5] - Describe how constant motion is the result of balanced (zero net) forces.
P.FM.05.33 [5] - Describe how changes in the motion of objects are caused by a non-zero net (unbalanced) force.
P.FM.05.34 [5] - Relate the size of change in motion to the strength of unbalanced forces and the mass of the object.

P.FM.M.4 [5] - Speed- Motion can be described by a change in position relative to a point of reference. The motion of an object can be described by its speed and the direction it is moving. The position and speed of an object can be measured and graphed as a function of time.
P.FM.05.41 [5] - Explain the motion of an object relative to its point of reference.
P.FM.05.42 [5] - Describe the motion of an object in terms of distance, time and direction, as the object moves, and in relationship to other objects.
P.FM.05.43 [5] - Illustrate how motion can be measured and represented on a graph.

[1-4,7] - K-7 Standard P.PM: Develop an understanding that all matter has observable attributes with physical and chemical properties that are described, measured, and compared Understand that states of matter exist as solid, liquid, or gas; and have physical and chemical properties. Understand all matter is composed of combinations of elements, which are organized by common attributes and characteristics on the Periodic Table. Understand that substances can be classified as mixtures or compounds and according to their physical and chemical properties.
P.PM.E.1 [1-2,4] - Physical Properties- All objects and substances have physical properties that can be measured.
P.PM.01.11 [1] - Demonstrate the ability to sort objects according to observable attributes such as color, shape, size, sinking or floating.
P.PM.02.12 [2] - Describe objects and substances according to their properties (color, size, shape, texture, hardness, liquid or solid, sinking or floating).
P.PM.02.13 [2] - Measure the length of objects using rulers (centimeters) and meter sticks (meters).
P.PM.02.14 [2] - Measure the volume of liquids using common measuring tools (measuring cups, measuring spoons).
P.PM.02.15 [2] - Compare the weight of objects using balances.
P.PM.04.16 [4] - Measure the weight (spring scale) and mass (balances in grams or kilograms) of objects.
P.PM.04.17 [4] - Measure volumes of liquids and capacities of containers in milliliters and liters.
P.PM.04.18 [4] - Demonstrate the use of centimeter cubes poured into a container to estimate the container's capacity.

P.PM.E.2 [1,4] - States of Matter- Matter exists in several different states: solids, liquids and gases. Each state of matter has unique physical properties. Gases are easily compressed but liquids and solids do not compress easily. Solids have their own particular shapes, but liquids and gases take the shape of the container.
P.PM.01.21 [1] - Demonstrate that water as a solid keeps its own shape (ice).
P.PM.01.22 [1] - Demonstrate that water as a liquid takes on the shape of various containers.
P.PM.04.23 [4] - Compare and contrast the states (solids, liquids, gases) of matter.
P.PM.E.3 [1,4] - Magnets- Magnets can repel or attract other magnets. Magnets can also attract certain non-magnetic objects at a distance.
P.PM.01.31 [1] - Identify materials that are attracted by magnets.
P.PM.01.32 [1] - Observe that like poles of a magnet repel and unlike poles of a magnet attract.
P.PM.04.33 [4] - Demonstrate magnetic field by observing the patterns formed with iron filings using a variety of magnets.
P.PM.04.34 [4] - Demonstrate that non-magnetic objects are affected by the strength of the magnet and the distance away from the magnet.
P.PM.E.4 [2] - Material Composition- Some objects are composed of a single substance, while other objects are composed of more than one substance.
P.PM.02.41 [2] - Classify objects as single substances (ice, silver, sugar, salt) or mixtures (salt and pepper, mixed dry beans).
P.PM.E.5 [3-4] - Conductive and Reflective Properties- Objects vary to the extent they absorb and reflect light energy and conduct heat and electricity.
P.PM.03.51 [3] - Demonstrate how some materials are heated more than others by light that shines on them.
P.PM.03.52 [3] - Explain how we need light to see objects: light from a source reflects off objects and enters our eyes.
P.PM.04.53 [4] - Identify objects that are good conductors or poor conductors of heat and electricity.
P.PM.M.1 [7] - Chemical Properties- Matter has chemical properties. The understanding of chemical properties helps to explain how new substances are formed.
P.PM.07.11 [7] - Classify substances by their chemical properties (flammability, pH, acid-base indicators, reactivity).

P.PM.M.2 [7] - Elements and Compounds- Elements are composed of a single kind of atom that are grouped into families with similar properties on the periodic table. Compounds are composed of two or more different elements. Each element and compound has a unique set of physical and chemical properties such as boiling point, density, color, conductivity, and reactivity.
P.PM.07.21 [7] - Identify the smallest component that makes up an element.

P.PM.07.22 [7] - Describe how the elements within the Periodic Table are organized by similar properties into families (highly reactive metals, less reactive metals, highly reactive nonmetals, and some almost completely non-reactive gases).
P.PM.07.23 [7] - Illustrate the structure of molecules using models or drawings (water, carbon dioxide, salt).
P.PM.07.24 [7] - List examples of physical and chemical properties of elements and compounds (boiling point, density, color, conductivity, reactivity).

[3-4,6-7] - K-7 Standard P.EN: Develop an understanding that there are many forms of energy (such as heat, light, sound, and electrical) and that energy is transferable by convection, conduction, or radiation. Understand energy can be in motion, called kinetic; or it can be stored, called potential. Develop an understanding that as temperature increases, more energy is added to a system. Understand nuclear reactions in the sun produce light and heat for the Earth.
P.EN.E.1 [3-4] - Forms of Energy- Heat, electricity, light, and sound are forms of energy.
P.EN.03.11 [3] - Identify light and sound as forms of energy.
P.EN.04.12 [4] - Identify heat and electricity as forms of energy.

P.EN.E.2 [3] - Light Properties- Light travels in straight lines. Shadows result from light not being able to pass through an object. When light travels at an angle from one substance to another (air and water), it changes direction.
P.EN.03.21 [3] - Demonstrate that light travels in a straight line and that shadows are made by placing an object in a path of light.
P.EN.03.22 [3] - Demonstrate what happens to light when it travels from water to air. (straw half in water looks bent).
P.EN.E.3 [3] - Sound- Vibrating objects produce sound. The pitch of sound varies by changing the rate of vibration.
P.EN.03.31 [3] - Relate sounds to their sources of vibrations (for example: a musical note produced by a vibrating guitar string, the sounds of a drum made by the vibrating drum head).
P.EN.03.32 [3] - Distinguish the effect of fast or slow vibrations as pitch.
P.EN.E.4 [4] - Energy and Temperature- Increasing the temperature of any substance requires the addition of energy.
P.EN.04.41 [4] - Demonstrate how temperature can be increased in a substance by adding energy.
P.EN.04.42 [4] - Describe heat as the energy produced when substances burn, certain kinds of materials rub against each other, and when electricity flows through wire.
P.EN.04.43 [4] - Describe how heat is produced through electricity, rubbing, and burning.
P.EN.E.5 [4] - Electrical Circuits- Electrical circuits transfer electrical energy and produce magnetic fields.
P.EN.04.51 [4] - Explain how electrical energy is transferred and changed through the use of a simple circuit.
P.EN.04.52 [4] - Create a simple working electromagnet and explain the conditions necessary to make the electromagnet.

P.EN.M.1 [6] - Kinetic and Potential Energy- Objects and substances in motion have kinetic energy. Objects and substances may have potential energy due to their relative positions in a system. Gravitational, elastic, and chemical energy are all forms of potential energy.
P.EN.06.11 [6] - Identify kinetic or potential energy in everyday situations (for example: stretched rubber band, objects in motion, ball on a hill, food energy).
P.EN.06.12 [6] - Demonstrate the transformation between potential and kinetic energy in simple mechanical systems (for example: roller coasters, pendulums).

P.EN.M.4 [6-7] - Energy Transfer- Energy is transferred from a source to a receiver by radiation, conduction, and convection. When energy is transferred from a source to a receiver, the quantity of energy before the transfer is equal to the quantity of energy after the transfer.
P.EN.06.41 [6] - Explain how different forms of energy can be transferred from one place to another by radiation, conduction, or convection.
P.EN.06.42 [6] - Illustrate how energy can be transferred while no energy is lost or gained in the transfer.
P.EN.07.43 [7] - Explain how light energy is transferred to chemical energy through the process of photosynthesis.
P.EN.M.3 [7] - Waves and Energy-Waves have energy and transfer energy when they interact with matter. Examples of waves include sound waves, seismic waves, waves on water, and light waves.
P.EN.07.31 [7] - Identify examples of waves, including sound waves, seismic waves, and waves on water.
P.EN.07.32 [7] - Describe how waves are produced by vibrations in matter.
P.EN.07.33 [7] - Demonstrate how waves transfer energy when they interact with matter (for example: tuning fork in water, waves hitting a beach, earthquake knocking over buildings).

P.EN.M.6 [7] - Solar Energy Effects- Nuclear reactions take place in the sun producing heat and light. Only a tiny fraction of the light energy from the sun reaches Earth, providing energy to heat the Earth.
P.EN.07.61 [7] - Identify that nuclear reactions take place in the sun, producing heat and light.
P.EN.07.62 [7] - Explain how only a tiny fraction of light energy from the sun is transformed to heat energy on Earth.

[4,6-7] - K-7 Standard P.CM: Develop an understanding of changes in the state of matter in terms of heating and cooling, and in terms of arrangement and relative motion of atoms and molecules. Understand the differences between physical and chemical changes. Develop an understanding of the conservation of mass. Develop an understanding of products and reactants in a chemical change.
P.CM.E.1 [4] - Changes in State- Matter can be changed from one state (liquid, solid, gas) to another and then back again. This may be caused by heating and cooling.
P.CM.04.11 [4] - Explain how matter can change from one state (liquid, solid, gas) to another by heating and cooling.

P.CM.M.1 [6] - Changes in State- Matter changing from state to state can be explained by using models which show that matter is composed of tiny particles in motion. When changes of state occur, the atoms and/or molecules are not changed in structure. When the changes in state occur, mass is conserved because matter is not created or destroyed.
P.CM.06.11 [6] - Describe and illustrate changes in state, in terms of the arrangement and relative motion of the atoms or molecules.
P.CM.06.12 [6] - Explain how mass is conserved as it changes from state to state in a closed system.

P.CM.M.2 [7] - Chemical Changes- Chemical changes occur when two elements and/or compounds react and produce new substances. These new substances have different physical and chemical properties than the original elements and/or compounds. During the chemical change, the number and kind of atoms in the reactants are the same as the number and kind of atoms in the products. Mass is conserved during chemical changes. The mass of the reactants is the same as the mass of the products.
P.CM.07.21 [7] - Identify evidence of chemical change through color, gas formation, solid formation, and temperature change.
P.CM.07.22 [7] - Compare and contrast the chemical properties of a new substance with the original after a chemical change.
P.CM.07.23 [7] - Describe the physical properties and chemical properties of the products and reactants in a chemical change.

[K-7] - K-7 Standard L.OL: Develop an understanding that plants and animals (including humans) have basic requirements for maintaining life which include the need for air, water and a source of energy. Understand that all life forms can be classified as producers, consumers, or decomposers as they are all part of a global food chain where food/energy is supplied by plants which need light to produce food/ energy. Develop an understanding that plants and animals can be classified by observable traits and physical characteristics. Understand that all living organisms are composed of cells and they exhibit cell growth and division. Understand that all plants and animals have a definite life cycle, body parts, and systems to perform specific life functions.

L.OL.E.1 [K-2,4] - Life Requirements- Organisms have basic needs. Animals and plants need air, water, and food. Plants also require light. Plants and animals use food as a source of energy and as a source of building material for growth and repair.
L.OL.00.11 [K] - Identify that living things have basic needs.
L.OL.00.12 [K] - Identify and compare living and nonliving things.
L.OL.01.13 [1] - Identify the needs of animals.
L.OL.02.14 [2] - Identify the needs of plants.
L.OL.04.15 [4] - Determine that plants require air, water, light, and a source of energy and building material for growth and repair.
L.OL.04.16 [4] - Determine that animals require air, water, and a source of energy and building material for growth and repair.

L.OL.E.2 [1-2] - Life Cycles- Plants and animals have life cycles. Both plants and animals begin life and develop into adults, reproduce, and eventually die. The details of this life cycle are different for different organisms.
L.OL.01.21 [1] - Describe the life cycle of animals including the following stages: egg, young, adult; egg, larva, pupa, adult.
L.OL.02.22 [2] - Describe the life cycle of familiar flowering plants including the following stages: seed, plant, flower, and fruit.
L.OL.E.3 [3] - Structures and Functions- Organisms have different structures that serve different functions in growth, survival, and reproduction.
L.OL.03.31 [3] - Describe the function of the following plant parts: flower, stem, root and leaf.
L.OL.03.32 [3] - Identify and compare structures in animals used for controlling body temperature, support, movement, food-getting, and protection (for example: fur, wings, teeth, claws).
L.OL.E.4 [3] - Classification- Organisms can be classified on the basis of observable characteristics.
L.OL.03.41 [3] - Classify plants on the basis of observable physical characteristics (roots, leaves, stems, and flowers).
L.OL.03.42 [3] - Classify animals on the basis of observable physical characteristics (backbone, skin, shell, limbs, scales).
L.OL.M.4 [5] - Animal Systems- Multicellular organisms may have specialized systems that perform functions which serve the needs of the organism.
L.OL.05.41 [5] - Identify the general purpose of selected animal systems (digestive, circulatory, respiratory, skeletal, muscular, nervous, excretory, and reproductive).
L.OL.05.42 [5] - Explain how animal systems (digestive, circulatory, respiratory, skeletal, muscular, nervous, excretory, and reproductive) work together to perform selected activities.

L.OL.M.5 [6] - Producers, Consumers, and Decomposers- All animals, including humans, are consumers that meet their energy by eating other organisms or their products. Consumers break down the structures of the organisms they eat to make the materials they need to grow and function. Decomposers, including bacteria and fungi, use dead organisms or their products to meet their energy needs.
L.OL.06.51 [6] - Classify organisms (producers, consumers, and decomposers) based on their source of energy for growth and development.
L.OL.06.52 [6] - Distinguish between the ways in which consumers and decomposers obtain energy.

L.OL.M.2 [7] - Cell Functions- All organisms are composed of cells, from one cell to many cells. In multicellular organisms, specialized cells perform specialized functions. Organs and organ systems are composed of cells, and function to serve the needs of cells for food, air, and waste removal. The way in which cells function is similar in all living organisms.
L.OL.07.21 [7] - Recognize that all organisms are composed of cells (single cell organisms, multicellular organisms).
L.OL.07.22 [7] - Explain how cells make up different body tissues, organs, and organ systems.

L.OL.07.23 [7] - Describe how cells in all multicellular organisms are specialized to take in nutrients, which they use to provide energy for the work that cells do and to make the materials that a cell or organism needs.
L.OL.07.24 [7] - Recognize that cells function in a similar way in all organisms.

L.OL.M.3 [7] - Growth and Development- Following fertilization, cell division produces a small cluster of cells that then differentiate by appearance and function to form the basic tissue of an embryo.
L.OL.07.31 [7] - Describe growth and development in terms of increase of cell number and/or cell size.
L.OL.07.32 [7] - Examine how through cell division, cells can become specialized for specific functions.

L.OL.M.6 [7] - Photosynthesis- Plants are producers; they use the energy from light to make sugar molecules from the atoms of carbon dioxide and water. Plants use these sugars along with minerals from the soil to form fats, proteins, and carbohydrates. These products can be used immediately, incorporated into the cells of a plant as the plant grows, or stored for later use.
L.OL.07.61 [7] - Recognize the need for light to provide energy for the production of carbohydrates, proteins and fats.
L.OL.07.62 [7] - Explain that carbon dioxide and water are used to produce carbohydrates, proteins, and fats.
L.OL.07.63 [7] - Describe evidence that plants make, use and store food.

[1-2,5,7] - K-7 Standard L.HE: Develop an understanding that all life forms must reproduce to survive. Understand that characteristics of mature plants and animals may be inherited or acquired and that only inherited traits are passed on to their young. Understand that inherited traits can be influenced by changes in the environment and by genetics.
L.HE.E.1 [1-2] - Observable Characteristics- Plants and animals share many, but not all, characteristics of their parents.
L.HE.01.11 [1] - Identify characteristics (for example: body coverings, beak shape, number of legs, body parts) that are passed on from parents to young.
L.HE.01.12 [1] - Classify young animals based on characteristics that are passed on from parents (for example: dogs/puppies, cats/kittens, cows/calves, chicken/chicks).
L.HE.02.13 [2] - Identify characteristics of plants (for example: leaf shape, flower type, color, size) that are passed on from parents to young.

L.HE.M.1 [5] - Inherited and Acquired Traits - The characteristics of organisms are influenced by heredity and environment. For some characteristics, inheritance is more important; for other characteristics, interactions with the environment are more important.
L.HE.05.11 [5] - Explain that the traits of an individual are influenced by both the environment and the genetics of the individual.
L.HE.05.12 [5] - Distinguish between inherited and acquired traits.

L.HE.M.2 [7] - Reproduction- Reproduction is a characteristic of all living systems; because no individual organism lives forever, reproduction is essential to the continuation of every species. Some organisms reproduce asexually. Other organisms reproduce sexually.
L.HE.07.21 [7] - Compare how characteristics of living things are passed on through generations, both asexually and sexually.
L.HE.07.22 [7] - Compare and contrast the advantages and disadvantages of sexual vs. asexual reproduction.

[3-5] - K-7 Standard L.EV: Develop an understanding that plants and animals have observable parts and characteristics that help them survive and flourish in their environments. Understand that fossils provide evidence that life forms have changed over time and were influenced by changes in environmental conditions. Understand that life forms either change (evolve) over time or risk extinction due to environmental changes and describe how scientists identify the relatedness of various organisms based on similarities in anatomical features.
L.EV.E.1 [3] - Environmental Adaptation- Different kinds of organisms have characteristics that help them to live in different environments.
L.EV.03.11 [3] - Relate characteristics and functions of observable parts in a variety of plants that allow them to live in their environment (for example: leaf shape, thorns, odor, color).
L.EV.03.12 [3] - Relate characteristics and functions of observable body parts to the ability of animals to live in their environment(for example: sharp teeth, claws, color, body covers).
L.EV.E.2 [4] - Survival- Individuals of the same kind differ in their characteristics, and sometimes the differences give individuals an advantage in surviving and reproducing.
L.EV.04.21 [4] - Identify individual differences (for example: color, leg length, size, wing size) in organisms of the same kind.
L.EV.04.22 [4] - Identify how variations in physical characteristics of individual organisms give them an advantage for survival and reproduction.

L.EV.M.1 [5] - Species Adaptation and Survival- Species with certain traits are more likely than others to survive and have offspring in particular environments. When an environment changes, the advantage or disadvantage of the species' characteristics can change. Extinction of a species occurs when the environment changes and the characteristics of a species are insufficient to allow survival.
L.EV.05.11 [5] - Explain how behavioral characteristics (adaptation, instinct, learning, habit) of animals help them to survive in their environment.
L.EV.05.12 [5] - Describe the physical characteristics (traits) of organisms that help them survive in their environment.
L.EV.05.13 [5] - Describe how fossils provide evidence about how living things and environmental conditions have changed.
L.EV.05.14 [5] - Analyze the relationship of environmental change and catastrophic events (for example: volcanic eruption, floods, asteroid impacts, tsunami) to species extinction.

L.EV.M.2 [5] - Relationships Among Organisms- Similarities among organisms are found in anatomical features, which can be used to infer the degree of relatedness among organisms. In classifying organisms, biologists consider details of internal and external structures to be more important than behavior or general appearance.
L.EV.05.21 [5] - Relate degree of similarity in anatomical features to the classification of contemporary organisms.

[4,6] - K-7 Standard L.EC: Develop an understanding of the interdependence of the variety of populations, communities and ecosystems, including those in the Great Lakes region. Develop an understanding of different types of interdependence and that biotic (living) and abiotic (non-living) factors affect the balance of an ecosystem. Understand that all organisms cause changes, some detrimental and others beneficial, in the environment where they live.

L.EC.E.1 [4] - Interactions- Organisms interact in various ways including providing food and shelter to one another. Some interactions are helpful: others are harmful to the organism and other organisms.
L.EC.04.11 [4] - Identify organisms as part of a food chain or food web.
L.EC.E.2 [4] - Changed Environment Effects- When the environment changes, some plants and animals survive to reproduce; others die or move to new locations.
L.EC.04.21 [4] - Explain how environmental changes can produce a change in the food web.

L.EC.M.1 [6] - Interactions of Organisms- Organisms of one species form a population. Populations of different organisms interact and form communities. Living communities and nonliving factors that interact with them form ecosystems.
L.EC.06.11 [6] - List examples of populations, communities, and ecosystems including the Great Lakes region.

L.EC.M.2 [6] - Relationships of Organisms- Two types of organisms may interact with one another in several ways: They may be in a producer/consumer, predator/ prey, or parasite/host relationship. Some organisms may scavenge or decompose another. Relationships may be competitive or mutually beneficial. Some species have become so adapted to each other that neither could survive without the other.
L.EC.06.21 [6] - Describe common patterns of relationships between and among populations (competition, parasitism, symbiosis, predator/prey).
L.EC.06.22 [6] - Explain how two populations of organisms can be mutually beneficial and how that can lead to interdependency.
L.EC.06.23 [6] - Predict how changes in one population might affect other populations based upon their relationships in the food web.

L.EC.M.3 [6] - Biotic and Abiotic Factors- The number of organisms and populations an ecosystem can support depends on the biotic (living) resources available and abiotic (nonliving) factors, such as quality of light and water, range of temperatures and soil composition.
L.EC.06.31 [6] - Identify the living (biotic) and nonliving (abiotic) components of an ecosystem.
L.EC.06.32 [6] - Identify the factors in an ecosystem that influence changes in population size.

L.EC.M.4 [6] - Environmental Impact of Organisms- All organisms (including humans) cause change in the environment where they live. Some of the changes are harmful to the organism or other organisms, whereas others are helpful.
L.EC.06.41 [6] - Describe how human beings are part of the ecosystem of the Earth and that human activity can purposefully, or accidentally, alter the balance in ecosystems.
L.EC.06.42 [6] - Predict possible consequences of overpopulation of organisms, including humans, (for example: species extinction, resource depletion, climate change, pollution).

[K-3,6] - K-7 Standard E.SE: Develop an understanding of the properties of earth materials and how those properties make materials useful. Understand gradual and rapid changes in earth materials and features of the surface of Earth. Understand magnetic properties of Earth.

E.SE.E.1 [K-1,3] - Earth Materials- Earth materials that occur in nature include rocks, minerals, soils, water, and the gases of the atmosphere. Some Earth materials have properties which sustain plant and animal life.
E.SE.00.11 [K] - Identify Earth materials (air, water, soil) that are used to grow plants.
E.SE.01.12 [1] - Describe how Earth materials contribute to the growth of plant and animal life.
E.SE.03.13 [3] - Recognize and describe different types of earth materials (mineral, rock, clay, boulder, gravel, sand, soil).
E.SE.03.14 [3] - Recognize that rocks are made up of minerals.

E.SE.E.2 [2-3] - Surface Changes- The surface of Earth changes. Some changes are due to slow processes, such as erosion and weathering, and some changes are due to rapid processes, such as landslides, volcanic eruptions, and earthquakes.
E.SE.02.21 [2] - Describe the major landforms of the surface of the Earth (mountains, plains, plateaus, valleys, hills).
E.SE.03.22 [3] - Identify and describe natural causes of change in the Earth's surface (erosion, glaciers, volcanoes, landslides, and earthquakes).

E.SE.E.3 [3] - Using Earth Materials- Some Earth materials have properties that make them useful either in their present form or designed and modified to solve human problems. They can enhance the quality of life as in the case of materials used for building or fuels used for heating and transportation.
E.SE.03.31 [3] - Identify Earth materials used to construct some common objects (for example: bricks, buildings, roads, glass).
E.SE.03.32 [3] - Describe how materials taken from the Earth can be used as fuels for heating and transportation.

E.SE.M.1 [6] - Soil- Soils consist of weathered rocks and decomposed organic materials from dead plants, animals, and bacteria. Soils are often found in layers with each having a different chemical composition and texture.
E.SE.06.11 [6] - Explain how physical and chemical weathering lead to erosion and the formation of soils and sediments.
E.SE.06.12 [6] - Explain how waves, wind, water, and glacier movement, shape and reshape the land surface of the Earth by eroding rock in some areas and depositing sediments in other areas.
E.SE.06.13 [6] - Describe how soil is a mixture, made up of weather eroded rock and decomposed organic material.
E.SE.06.14 [6] - Compare different soil samples based on particle size and texture.
E.SE.M.4 [6] - Rock Formation- Rocks and rock formations bear evidence of the minerals, materials, temperature/pressure conditions, and forces that created them.
E.SE.06.41 [6] - Compare and contrast the formation of rock types (igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary) and demonstrate the similarities and differences using the rock cycle model.
E.SE.M.5 [6] - Plate Tectonics- The lithospheric plates of the Earth constantly move, resulting in major geological events, such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and mountain building.
E.SE.06.51 [6] - Explain plate tectonic movement and how the lithospheric plates move centimeters each year.
E.SE.06.52 [6] - Demonstrate how major geological events (earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, mountain building) result from these plate motions.
E.SE.06.53 [6] - Describe layers of the Earth as a lithosphere (crust and upper mantle), convecting mantle, and dense metallic core.
E.SE.M.6 [6] - Magnetic Field of Earth- Earth as a whole has a magnetic field that is detectable at the surface with a compass.
E.SE.06.61 [6] - Describe the Earth as a magnet and compare the magnetic properties of the Earth to that of a natural or man-made magnet.
E.SE.06.62 [6] - Explain how a compass works using the magnetic field of the Earth, and how a compass is used for navigation on land and sea.

[1,3,5,7] - K-7 Standard E.ES: Develop an understanding of the warming of the Earth by the sun as the major source of energy for phenomenon on Earth and how the sun's warming relates to weather, climate, seasons, and the water cycle. Understand how human interaction and use of natural resources affects the environment.
E.ES.E.1 [1] - Solar Energy- The sun warms the land, air and water and helps plants grow.
E.ES.01.11 [1] - Identify the sun as the most important source of heat which warms the land, air, and water of the Earth.
E.ES.01.12 [1] - Demonstrate the importance of sunlight and warmth in plant growth.
E.ES.E.2 [1] - Weather- Weather changes from day to day and over the seasons.

E.ES.01.21 [1] - Compare daily changes in the weather related to temperature (cold, hot, warm, cool); cloud cover (cloudy, partly cloudy, foggy) precipitation (rain, snow, hail, freezing rain); wind (breezy, windy, calm).
E.ES.01.22 [1] - Describe and compare weather related to the four seasons in terms of temperature, cloud cover, precipitation, and wind.
E.ES.01.24 [1] - Describe precautions that should be taken for human safety during severe weather conditions (thunderstorms, lightning, tornadoes, high winds, blizzards, hurricanes).
E.ES.E.3 [1] - Weather Measurement- Scientists use tools for observing, recording, and predicting weather changes.
E.ES.01.31 [1] - Identify the tools that might be used to measure temperature, precipitation, cloud cover and wind.
E.ES.01.32 [1] - Observe and collect data of weather conditions over a period of time.
E.ES.E.4 [3] - Natural Resources- The supply of many natural resources is limited. Humans have devised methods for extending their use of natural resources through recycling, reuse, and renewal.
E.ES.03.41 [3] - Identify natural resources (metals, fuels, fresh water, farmland, and forests).
E.ES.03.42 [3] - Classify renewable (fresh water, farmland, forests) and non-renewable (fuels, metals) resources.
E.ES.03.43 [3] - Describe ways humans are protecting, extending, and restoring resources (recycle, reuse, reduce, renewal).
E.ES.03.44 [3] - Recognize that paper, metal, glass, and some plastics can be recycled.
E.ES.E.5 [3] - Human Impact- Humans depend on their natural and constructed environment. Humans change environments in ways that are helpful or harmful for themselves and other organisms.

E.ES.03.51 [3] - Describe ways humans are dependent on the natural environment (forests, water, clean air, earth materials) and constructed environments (homes, neighborhoods, shopping malls, factories, and industry).
E.ES.03.52 [3] - Describe helpful or harmful effects of humans on the environment (garbage, habitat destruction, land management, renewable and non-renewable resources).

E.ES.M.6 [5] - Seasons- Seasons result from annual variations in the intensity of sunlight and length of day due to the tilt of the axis of the Earth relative to the plane of its yearly orbit around the sun.
E.ES.05.61 [5] - Demonstrate using a model, seasons as the result of variations in the intensity of sunlight caused by the tilt of the Earth on its axis, and revolution around the sun.
E.ES.05.62 [5] - Explain how the revolution of the Earth around the sun defines a year.
E.ES.M.1 [7] - Solar Energy- The sun is the major source of energy for phenomena on the surface of the Earth.

E.ES.07.11 [7] - Demonstrate, using a model or drawing, the relationship between the warming by the sun of the Earth and the water cycle as it applies to the atmosphere (evaporation, water vapor, warm air rising, cooling, condensation, clouds).
E.ES.07.12 [7] - Describe the relationship between the warming of the atmosphere of the Earth by the sun and convection within the atmosphere and oceans.
E.ES.07.13 [7] - Describe how the warming of the Earth by the sun produces winds and ocean currents.

E.ES.M.4 [7] - Human Consequences- Human activities have changed the land, oceans, and atmosphere of the Earth resulting in the reduction of the number and variety of wild plants and animals sometimes causing extinction of species.

E.ES.07.41 [7] - Explain how human activities (surface mining, deforestation, overpopulation, construction and urban development, farming, dams, landfills, and restoring natural areas) change the surface of the Earth and affect the survival of organisms.

E.ES.07.42 [7] - Describe the origins of pollution in the atmosphere, geosphere, and hydrosphere, (car exhaust, industrial emissions, acid rain, and natural sources), and how pollution impacts habitats, climatic change, threatens or endangers species.
E.ES.M.7 [7] - Weather and Climate- Global patterns of atmospheric and oceanic movement influence weather and climate.
E.ES.07.71 [7] - Compare and contrast the difference and relationship between climate and weather.
E.ES.07.72 [7] - Describe how different weather occurs due to the constant motion of the atmosphere from the energy of the sun reaching the surface of the Earth.
E.ES.07.73 [7] - Explain how the temperature of the oceans affects the different climates on Earth because water in the oceans holds a large amount of heat.

E.ES.07.74 [7] - Describe weather conditions associated with frontal boundaries (cold, warm, stationary, and occluded) and the movement of major air masses and the jet stream across North America using a weather map.
E.ES.M.8 [7] - Water Cycle- Water circulates through the four spheres of the Earth in what is known as the "water cycle."

E.ES.07.81 [7] - Explain the water cycle and describe how evaporation, transpiration, condensation, cloud formation, precipitation, infiltration, surface runoff, ground water, and absorption occur within the cycle.
E.ES.07.82 [7] - Analyze the flow of water between the components of a watershed, including surface features (lakes, streams, rivers, wetlands) and groundwater.

[2,7] - K-7 Standard E.FE: Develop an understanding that Earth is a planet nearly covered with water and that water on Earth can be found in three states, solid, liquid, and gas. Understand how water on Earth moves in predictable patterns. Understand Earth's atmosphere as a mixture of gases and water vapor.

E.FE.E.1 [2] - Water- Water is a natural resource and is found under the ground, on the surface of the earth, and in the sky. It exists in three states (liquid, solid, gas) and can go back and forth from one form to another.
E.FE.02.11 [2] - Identify water sources (wells, springs, lakes, rivers, oceans).
E.FE.02.12 [2] - Identify household uses of water (drinking, cleaning, food preparation).
E.FE.02.13 [2] - Describe the properties (visible, flowing, melting, dew) of water as a liquid (lakes, rivers, streams, oceans).
E.FE.02.14 [2] - Describe the properties (hard, visible, freezing, ice) of water as a solid (ice, snow, iceberg, sleet, hail).
E.FE.E.2 [2] - Water Movement- Water moves in predictable patterns.
E.FE.02.21 [2] - Describe how rain collects on the surface of the Earth and flows downhill into bodies of water (streams, rivers, lakes, oceans) or into the ground.
E.FE.02.22 [2] - Describe the major bodies of water on the Earth's surface (lakes, ponds, oceans, rivers, streams).

E.FE.M.1 [7] - Atmosphere- The atmosphere is a mixture of nitrogen, oxygen and trace gases that include water vapor. The atmosphere has different physical and chemical composition at different elevations.
E.FE.07.11 [7] - Describe the atmosphere as a mixture of gases.
E.FE.07.12 [7] - Compare and contrast the composition of the atmosphere at different elevations.

[4-6] - K-7 Standard E.ST: Develop an understanding that the sun is the central and largest body in the solar system and that Earth and other objects in the sky move in a regular and predictable motion around the sun. Understand that those motions explain the day, year, moon phases, eclipses and the appearance of motion of objects across the sky. Understand that gravity is the force that keeps the planets in orbit around the sun and governs motion in the solar system. Develop an understanding that fossils and layers of Earth provide evidence of the history of Earth's life forms, changes over long periods of time, and theories regarding Earth's history and continental drift.
E.ST.E.1 [4] - Characteristics of Objects in the Sky- Common objects in the sky have observable characteristics.
E.ST.04.11 [4] - Identify common objects in the sky, such as the sun and the moon.
E.ST.04.12 [4] - Compare and contrast the characteristics of the sun, moon and Earth, including relative distances and abilities to support life.
E.ST.E.2 [4] - Patterns of Objects in the Sky- Common objects in the sky have observable characteristics and predictable patterns of movement.
E.ST.04.21 [4] - Describe the orbit of the Earth around the sun as it defines a year.
E.ST.04.22 [4] - Explain that the spin of the Earth creates day and night.
E.ST.04.23 [4] - Describe the motion of the moon around the Earth.
E.ST.04.24 [4] - Explain how the visible shape of the moon follows a predictable cycle which takes approximately one month.
E.ST.04.25 [4] - Describe the apparent movement of the sun and moon across the sky through day/night and the seasons.
E.ST.E.3 [4] - Fossils- Fossils provide evidence about the plants and animals that lived long ago and the nature of the environment at that time.
E.ST.04.31 [4] - Explain how fossils provide evidence of the history of the Earth.
E.ST.04.32 [4] - Compare and contrast life forms found in fossils and organisms that exist today.

E.ST.M.1 [5] - Solar System- The sun is the central and largest body in our solar system. Earth is the third planet from the sun in a system that includes other planets and their moons, as well as smaller objects, such as asteroids and comets.
E.ST.05.11 [5] - Design a model that describes the position and relationship of the planets and other objects (comets and asteroids) to the sun.
E.ST.M.2 [5] - Solar System Motion- Gravity is the force that keeps most objects in the solar system in regular and predictable motion.
E.ST.05.21 [5] - Describe the motion of planets and moons in terms of rotation on axis and orbits due to gravity.
E.ST.05.22 [5] - Explain moon phases as they relate to the position of the moon in its orbit around the Earth, resulting in the amount of observable reflected light.
E.ST.05.23 [5] - Recognize that nighttime objects (stars and constellations) and the sun appear to move because the Earth rotates on its axis and orbits the sun.
E.ST.05.24 [5] - Explain lunar and solar eclipses based on the relative positions of the Earth, moon, and sun, and the orbit of the moon.
E.ST.05.25 [5] - Explain the tides of the oceans as they relate to the gravitational pull and orbit of the moon.
E.ST.M.3 [6] - Fossils- Fossils provide important evidence of how life and environmental conditions have changed in a given location.
E.ST.06.31 [6] - Explain how rocks and fossils are used to understand the age and geological history of the earth (timelines and relative dating, rock layers).

E.ST.M.4 [6] - Geologic Time- Earth processes seen today (erosion, mountain building, and glacier movement) make possible the measurement of geologic time through methods such as observing rock sequences and using fossils to correlate the sequences at various locations.
E.ST.06.41 [6] - Explain how Earth processes (erosion, mountain building, and glacier movement) are used for the measurement of geologic time through observing rock layers.
E.ST.06.42 [6] - Describe how fossils provide important evidence of how life and environmental conditions have changed.
MI - Social Studies Grade Level Content Expectations (K-8)
K – H2.0.1 [K] - Distinguish among yesterday, today, tomorrow.
K – H2.0.2 [K] - Create a timeline using events from their own lives (e.g., birth, crawling, walking, loss of first tooth, first day of school).
K – H2.0.3 [K] - Identify the beginning, middle, and end of historical narratives or stories.
K – H2.0.4 [K] - Describe ways people learn about the past (e.g., photos, artifacts, diaries, stories, videos).
K – G1.0.1 [K] - Recognize that maps and globes represent places.
K – G1.0.2 [K] - Use environmental directions or positional words (up/down, in/out, above/below) to identify significant locations in the classroom.
K – G2.0.1 [K] - Identify and describe places in the immediate environment (e.g., classroom, home, playground).
K – G5.0.1 [K] - Describe ways people use the environment to meet human needs and wants (e.g., food, shelter, clothing).
[K] - Values and Principles of American Democracy
K – C2.0.1 [K] - Identify our country's flag as an important symbol of the United States.
K – C2.0.2 [K] - Explain why people do not have the right to do whatever they want (e.g., to promote fairness, ensure the common good, maintain safety).
K – C2.0.3 [K] - Describe fair ways for groups to make decisions.
[K] - Role of the Citizen in American Democracy

K – C5.0.1 [K] - Describe situations in which they demonstrated self-discipline and individual responsibility (e.g., caring for a pet, completing chores, following school rules, working in a group, taking turns).
K - E1.0.1 [K] - Describe economic wants they have experienced.
K - E1.0.2 [K] - Distinguish between goods and services.
K - E1.0.3 [K] - Recognize situations in which people trade.
[K] - Public Discourse, Decision Making, and Citizen Involvement
K – P3.1.2 [K] - Use simple graphs to explain information about a classroom issue.
K – P3.1.3 [K] - Compare their viewpoint about a classroom issue with the viewpoint of another person.
[K] - Persuasive Communication About a Public Issue
K – P3.3.1 [K] - Express a position on a classroom issue.
K – P4.2.1 [K] - Develop and implement an action plan to address or inform others about a public issue.
K – P4.2.2 [K] - Participate in projects to help or inform others.
[1] - Living and Working Together in Families and Schools
1 – H2.0.1 [1] - Demonstrate chronological thinking by distinguishing among past, present, and future using family or school events.
1 – H2.0.2 [1] - Use a calendar to distinguish among days, weeks, and months.
1 – H2.0.3 [1] - Investigate a family history for at least two generations, identifying various members and their connections in order to tell a narrative about family life.
1 – H2.0.4 [1] - Retell in sequence important ideas and details from stories about families or schools.
1 – H2.0.5 [1] - Use historical records and artifacts (e.g., photos, diaries, oral histories, and videos) to draw possible conclusions about family or school life in the past.
1 – H2.0.6 [1] - Compare life today with life in the past using the criteria of family, school, jobs, or communication.

1 – H2.0.7 [1] - Identify the events or people celebrated during United States national holidays and why we celebrate them (e.g., Independence Day, Constitution Day, Martin Luther King, Jr. Day; Presidents' Day).
1 – G1.0.1 [1] - Construct simple maps of the classroom to demonstrate aerial perspective.
1 – G1.0.2 [1] - Give examples of places that have absolute locations (e.g., home address, school address).
1 – G1.0.3 [1] - Use personal directions (left, right, front, back) to describe the relative location of significant places in the school environment.
1 – G1.0.4 [1] - Distinguish between landmasses and bodies of water using maps and globes.
1 – G2.0.1 [1] - Distinguish between physical (e.g., clouds, trees, weather) and human (e.g., buildings, playgrounds, sidewalks) characteristics of places.
1 – G2.0.2 [1] - Describe the unifying characteristics and/or boundaries of different school regions (e.g., playground, reading corner, library, restroom).
1 – G4.0.1 [1] - Use components of culture (e.g., foods, language, religion, traditions) to describe diversity in family life.
1 – G5.0.1 [1] - Describe ways in which people modify (e.g., cutting down trees, building roads) and adapt to the environment (e.g., clothing, housing, transportation).
1 – C1.0.1 [1] - Identify some reasons for rules in school (e.g., provide order, predictability, and safety).
1 – C1.0.2 [1] - Give examples of the use of power with authority in school (e.g., principal, teacher or bus driver enforcing school rules).
1 – C1.0.3 [1] - Give examples of the use of power without authority in school (e.g., types of bullying, taking cuts in line).
[1] - Values and Principles of American Democracy
1 – C2.0.1 [1] - Explain how decisions can be made or how conflicts might be resolved in fair and just ways (e.g., majority rules).
1 – C2.0.2 [1] - Identify important symbols of the United States of America (e.g., Statue of Liberty, Uncle Sam, White House, Bald Eagle).
[1] - Roles of the Citizen in American Democracy
1 – C5.0.1 [1] - Describe some responsibilities people have at home and at school (e.g., taking care of oneself, respect for the rights of others, following rules, getting along with others).

1 – C5.0.2 [1] - Identify situations in which people act as good citizens in the school community (e.g., thoughtful and effective participation in the school decisions, respect for the rights of others, respect for rule of law, voting, volunteering, compassion, courage, honesty).
1 – E1.0.1 [1] - Distinguish between producers and consumers of goods and services.
1 – E1.0.2 [1] - Describe ways in which families consume goods and services.
1 – E1.0.3 [1] - Using examples, explain why people cannot have everything they want (scarcity) and describe how people respond (choice).
1 – E1.0.4 [1] - Describe reasons why people voluntarily trade.
1 – E1.0.5 [1] - Describe ways in which people earn money (e.g., providing goods and services to others, jobs).
1 – E1.0.6 [1] - Describe how money simplifies trade.
[1] - Public Discourse, Decision Making, and Citizen Involvement
1 – P3.1.1 [1] - Identify public issues in the school community.
1 – P3.1.2 [1] - Use graphic data to analyze information about a public issue in the school community.
1 – P3.1.3 [1] - Identify alternative resolutions to a public issue in the school community.
[1] - Persuasive Communication About a Public Issue
1 – P3.3.1 [1] - Express a position on a public policy issue in the school community and justify the position with a reasoned argument.
1 – P4.2.1 [1] - Develop and implement an action plan to address or inform others about a public issue.
1 – P4.2.2 [1] - Participate in projects to help or inform others.
[2] - Living and Working Together in Communities
2 – H2.0.1 [2] - Demonstrate chronological thinking by distinguishing among years and decades using a timeline of local community events.
2 – H2.0.2 [2] - Explain why descriptions of the same event in the local community can be different.
2 – H2.0.3 [2] - Use an example to describe the role of the individual in creating history.
2 – H2.0.4 [2] - Describe changes in the local community over time (e.g., types of businesses, architecture and landscape, jobs, transportation, population).
2 – H2.0.5 [2] - Identify a problem in a community's past and describe how it was resolved.
2 – H2.0.6 [2] - Construct a historical narrative about the history of the local community from a variety of sources (e.g., data gathered from local residents, artifacts, photographs).
2 – G1.0.1 [2] - Construct maps of the local community that contain symbols, labels, and legends denoting human and natural characteristics of place.
2 – G1.0.2 [2] - Use maps to describe the spatial organization of the local community by applying concepts including relative location and using distance, direction, and scale.
2 – G2.0.1 [2] - Compare the physical and human characteristics of the local community with those of another community.
2 – G2.0.2 [2] - Describe how the local community is part of a larger region (e.g., county, metropolitan area, state).
2 – G4.0.1 [2] - Describe land use in the community (e.g., where people live, where services are provided, where products are made).
2 – G4.0.2 [2] - Describe the means people create for moving people, goods, and ideas within the local community.
2 – G4.0.3 [2] - Use components of culture (e.g., foods, language, religion, traditions) to describe diversity in the local community.
2 – G5.0.1 [2] - Suggest ways people can responsibly interact with the environment in the local community.
2 – G5.0.2 [2] - Describe positive and negative consequences of changing the physical environment of the local community.
2 – C1.0.1 [2] - Explain why people form governments.
2 – C1.0.2 [2] - Distinguish between government action and private action.
[2] - Values and Principles of American Democracy
2 – C2.0.1 [2] - Explain how local governments balance individual rights with the common good to solve local community problems.
2 – C2.0.2 [2] - Describe how the Pledge of Allegiance reflects the core democratic value of patriotism.
2 – C3.0.1 [2] - Give examples of how local governments make, enforce, and interpret laws (ordinances) in the local community.
2 – C3.0.2 [2] - Use examples to describe how local government affects the lives of its citizens.
2 – C3.0.3 [2] - Identify services commonly provided by local governments (e.g., police, fire departments, schools, libraries, parks).
[2] - Roles of the Citizen in American Democracy
2 – C5.0.1 [2] - Identify ways citizens participate in community decisions.
2 – C5.0.2 [2] - Distinguish between personal and civic responsibilities and explain why they are important in community life.
2 – C5.0.3 [2] - Design and participate in community improvement projects that help or inform others. (See P4.2.2)
2 – E1.0.1 [2] - Identify the opportunity cost involved in a consumer decision.
2 – E1.0.2 [2] - Identify businesses in the local community.
2 – E1.0.3 [2] - Describe how businesses in the local community meet economic wants of consumers.
2 – E1.0.4 [2] - Describe the natural, human, and capital resources needed for production of a good or service in a community.
2 – E1.0.5 [2] - Use examples to show that people cannot produce everything they want (specialization) and depend on trade with others to meet their wants.
[2] - Public Discourse, Decision Making, and Citizen Involvement
2 – P3.1.1 [2] - Identify public issues in the local community that influence the daily lives of its citizens.
2 – P3.1.2 [2] - Use graphic data and other sources to analyze information about a public issue in the local community and evaluate alternative resolutions.
2 – P3.1.3 [2] - Give examples of how conflicts over core democratic values lead people to differ on resolutions to a public policy issue in the local community.
[2] - Persuasive Communication About a Public Issue
2 – P3.3.1 [2] - Compose a statement expressing a position on a public policy issue in the local community and justify the position with a reasoned argument.
2 – P4.2.1 [2] - Develop and implement an action plan to address or inform others about a public issue.
2 – P4.2.2 [2] - Participate in projects to help or inform others.
3 – H3.0.1 [3] - Identify questions historians ask in examining the past in Michigan (e.g., What happened? When did it happen? Who was involved? How and why did it happen?)
3 – H3.0.2 [3] - Explain how historians use primary and secondary sources to answer questions about the past.
3 – H3.0.3 [3] - Describe the causal relationships between three events in Michigan's past (e.g., Erie Canal, more people came, statehood).

3 – H3.0.4 [3] - Draw upon traditional stories of American Indians (e.g., Anishinaabeg - Ojibway (Chippewa), Odawa (Ottawa), Potawatomi; Menominee; Huron Indians) who lived in Michigan in order to make generalizations about their beliefs.
3 – H3.0.5 [3] - Use informational text and visual data to compare how American Indians and settlers in the early history of Michigan adapted to, used, and modified their environment.
3 – H3.0.6 [3] - Use a variety of sources to describe interactions that occurred between American Indians and the first European explorers and settlers in Michigan.
3 – H3.0.7 [3] - Use a variety of primary and secondary sources to construct a historical narrative about daily life in the early settlements of Michigan (pre-statehood).
3 – H3.0.8 [3] - Use case studies or stories to describe how the ideas or actions of individuals affected the history of Michigan.
3 – H3.0.9 [3] - Describe how Michigan attained statehood.
3 – H3.0.10 [3] - Create a timeline to sequence early Michigan history (American Indians, exploration, settlement, statehood).
3 – G1.0.1 [3] - Use cardinal directions (north, south, east, west) to describe the relative location of significant places in the immediate environment.
3 – G1.0.2 [3] - Use thematic maps to identify and describe the physical and human characteristics of Michigan.
3 – G2.0.1 [3] - Use a variety of visual materials and data sources to describe ways in which Michigan can be divided into regions.
3 – G2.0.2 [3] - Describe different regions to which Michigan belongs (e.g., Great Lakes Region, Midwest).

3 – G4.0.1 [3] - Describe major kinds of economic activity in Michigan today, such as agriculture (e.g., corn, cherries, dairy), manufacturing (e.g., automobiles, wood products), services and tourism, research and development (e.g., Automation Alley, life sciences corridor, university communities), and explain the factors influencing the location of these economic activities. (E)
3 – G4.0.2 [3] - Describe diverse groups that have come into a region of Michigan and reasons why they came (push/pull factors). (H)
3 – G4.0.3 [3] - Describe some of the current movements of goods, people, jobs or information to, from, or within Michigan and explain reasons for the movements. (E)

3 – G4.0.4 [3] - Use data and current information about the Anishinaabeg and other American Indians living in Michigan today to describe the cultural aspects of modern American Indian life; give an example of how another cultural group in Michigan today has preserved and built upon its cultural heritage.
3 – G5.0.1 [3] - Locate natural resources in Michigan and explain the consequences of their use.
3 – G5.0.2 [3] - Describe how people adapt to, use, and modify the natural resources of Michigan. (H)

3 – C1.0.1 [3] - Give an example of how Michigan state government fulfills one of the purposes of government (e.g., protecting individual rights, promoting the common good, ensuring equal treatment under the law).
[3] - Values and Principles of American Government
3 – C2.0.1 [3] - Describe how Michigan state government reflects the principle of representative government.
3 – C3.0.1 [3] - Distinguish between the roles of state and local government.
3 – C3.0.2 [3] - Identify goods and services provided by the state government and describe how they are funded (e.g., taxes, fees, fines).
3 – C3.0.3 [3] - Identify the three branches of state government in Michigan and the powers of each.
3 – C3.0.4 [3] - Explain how state courts function to resolve conflict.
3 – C3.0.5 [3] - Describe the purpose of the Michigan Constitution.
[3] - Roles of the Citizen in American Democracy

3 – C5.0.1 [3] - Identify rights (e.g., freedom of speech, freedom of religion, right to own property) and responsibilities of citizenship (e.g., respecting the rights of others, voting, obeying laws).
3 – E1.0.1 [3] - Explain how scarcity, opportunity costs, and choices affect what is produced and consumed in Michigan.
3 – E1.0.2 [3] - Identify incentives (e.g., sales, tax breaks) that influence economic decisions people make in Michigan.

3 – E1.0.3 [3] - Analyze how Michigan's location and natural resources influenced its economic development (e.g., how waterways and other natural resources have influenced economic activities such as mining, lumbering, automobile manufacturing, and furniture making). (H, G)
3 – E1.0.4 [3] - Describe how entrepreneurs combine natural, human, and capital resources to produce goods and services in Michigan. (H, G)
3 – E1.0.5 [3] - Explain the role of business development in Michigan's economic future.

3 – E2.0.1 [3] - Using a Michigan example, describe how specialization leads to increased interdependence (cherries grown in Michigan are sold in Florida; oranges grown in Florida are sold in Michigan).
3 – E3.0.1 [3] - Identify products produced in other countries and consumed by people in Michigan.
[3] - Public Discourse, Decision Making, and Citizen Involvement
3 – P3.1.1 [3] - Identify public issues in Michigan that influence the daily lives of its citizens.
3 – P3.1.2 [3] - Use graphic data and other sources to analyze information about a public issue in Michigan and evaluate alternative resolutions.
3 – P3.1.3 [3] - Give examples of how conflicts over core democratic values lead people to differ on resolutions to a public policy issue in Michigan.
[3] - Persuasive Communication About a Public Issue
3 – P3.3.1 [3] - Compose a paragraph expressing a position on a public policy issue in Michigan and justify the position with a reasoned argument.
3 – P4.2.1 [3] - Develop and implement an action plan and know how, when, and where to address or inform others about a public issue.
3 – P4.2.2 [3] - Participate in projects to help or inform others.

4 – H3.0.1 [4] - Use historical inquiry questions to investigate the development of Michigan's major economic activities (agriculture, mining, manufacturing, lumbering, tourism, technology, and research) from statehood to present. (C, E)
  • What happened?
  • When did it happen?
  • Who was involved?
  • How and why did it happen?
  • How does it relate to other events or issues in the past, in the present, or in the future?
  • What is its significance?
4 – H3.0.2 [4] - Use primary and secondary sources to explain how migration and immigration affected and continue to affect the growth of Michigan. (G)

4 – H3.0.3 [4] - Describe how the relationship between the location of natural resources and the location of industries (after 1837) affected and continues to affect the location and growth of Michigan cities. (G, E)

4 – H3.0.4 [4] - Draw upon stories, photos, artifacts, and other primary sources to compare the life of people in towns and cities in Michigan and in the Great Lakes region during a variety of time periods from 1837 to the present (e.g., 1837-1900, 1900-1950, 1950-2000). (G)
4 – H3.0.5 [4] - Use visual data and informational text or primary accounts to compare a major Michigan economic activity today with that same or a related activity in the past. (E)
4 – H3.0.6 [4] - Use a variety of primary and secondary sources to construct a historical narrative about the beginnings of the automobile industry and the labor movement in Michigan. (G, E)

4 – H3.0.7 [4] - Use case studies or stories to describe the ideas and actions of individuals involved in the Underground Railroad in Michigan and in the Great Lakes region. (See 8-U4.2.2; 8-U4.3.2; 8-U5.1.5; USHG 7.2.4) (G, C, E)
4 – H3.0.8 [4] - Describe past and current threats to Michigan's natural resources; describe how Michigan worked in the past and continues to work today to protect its natural resources. (G, C, E)

4 – G1.0.1 [4] - Identify questions geographers ask in examining the United States (e.g., Where it is? What is it like there? How is it connected to other places?).
4 – G1.0.2 [4] - Use cardinal and intermediate directions to describe the relative location of significant places in the United States.

4 – G1.0.3 [4] - Identify and describe the characteristics and purposes (e.g., measure distance, determine relative location, classify a region) of a variety of geographic tools and technologies (e.g., globe, map, satellite image).
4 – G1.0.4 [4] - Use geographic tools and technologies, stories, songs, and pictures to answer geographic questions about the United States.
4 – G1.0.5 [4] - Use maps to describe elevation, climate, and patterns of population density in the United States.
4 – G2.0.1 [4] - Describe ways in which the United States can be divided into different regions (e.g., political regions, economic regions, landform regions, vegetation regions).
4 – G2.0.2 [4] - Compare human and physical characteristics of a region to which Michigan belongs (e.g., Great Lakes, Midwest) with those of another region in the United States.
4 – G4.0.1 [4] - Use a case study or story about migration within or to the United States to identify push and pull factors (why they left, why they came) that influenced the migration. (H)
4 – G4.0.2 [4] - Describe the impact of immigration to the United States on the cultural development of different places or regions of the United States (e.g., forms of shelter, language, food). (H)
4 – G5.0.1 [4] - Assess the positive and negative effects of human activities on the physical environment of the United States.

4 – C1.0.1 [4] - Identify questions political scientists ask in examining the United States (e.g., What does government do? What are the basic values and principles of American democracy? What is the relationship of the United States to other nations? What are the roles of the citizen in American democracy?).
4 – C1.0.2 [4] - Explain probable consequences of an absence of government and of rules and laws.
4 – C1.0.3 [4] - Describe the purposes of government as identified in the Preamble of the Constitution.
[4] - Values and Principles of American Democracy

4 – C2.0.1 [4] - Explain how the principles of popular sovereignty, rule of law, checks and balances, separation of powers, and individual rights (e.g., freedom of religion, freedom of expression, freedom of press) serve to limit the powers of the federal government as reflected in the Constitution and Bill of Rights.
4 – C2.0.2 [4] - Identify situations in which specific rights guaranteed by the Constitution and Bill of Rights are involved (e.g., freedom of religion, freedom of expression, freedom of press).
4 – C3.0.1 [4] - Give examples of ways the Constitution limits the powers of the federal government (e.g., election of public officers, separation of powers, checks and balances, Bill of Rights).
4 – C3.0.2 [4] - Give examples of powers granted to the federal government (e.g., coining of money, declaring war) and those reserved for the states (e.g., driver's license, marriage license).
4 – C3.0.3 [4] - Describe the organizational structure of the federal government in the United States (legislative, executive, and judicial branches).
4 – C3.0.4 [4] - Describe how the powers of the federal government are separated among the branches.

4 – C3.0.5 [4] - Give examples of how the system of checks and balances limits the power of the federal government (e.g., presidential veto of legislation, courts declaring a law unconstitutional, congressional approval of judicial appointments).
4 – C3.0.6 [4] - Describe how the President, members of the Congress, and justices of the Supreme Court come to power (e.g., elections versus appointments).
4 – C3.0.7 [4] - Explain how the federal government uses taxing and spending to serve the purposes of government.
[4] - Roles of the Citizen in American Democracy

4 – C5.0.1 [4] - Explain responsibilities of citizenship (e.g., initiating changes in laws or policy, holding public office, respecting the law, being informed and attentive to public issues, paying taxes, registering to vote and voting knowledgeably, serving as a juror).
4 – C5.0.2 [4] - Describe the relationship between rights and responsibilities of citizenship.
4 – C5.0.3 [4] - Explain why rights have limits.
4 – C5.0.4 [4] - Describe ways citizens can work together to promote the values and principles of American democracy.

4 – E1.0.1 [4] - Identify questions economists ask in examining the United States (e.g., What is produced? How is it produced? How much is produced? Who gets what is produced? What role does the government play in the economy?).
4 – E1.0.2 [4] - Describe some characteristics of a market economy (e.g., private property rights, voluntary exchange, competition, consumer sovereignty, incentives, specialization).
4 – E1.0.3 [4] - Describe how positive and negative incentives influence behavior in a market economy.
4 – E1.0.4 [4] - Explain how price affects decisions about purchasing goods and services (substitute goods).
4 – E1.0.5 [4] - Explain how specialization and division of labor increase productivity (e.g., assembly line). (H)
4 – E1.0.6 [4] - Explain how competition among buyers results in higher prices and competition among sellers results in lower prices (e.g., supply, demand).
4 – E1.0.7 [4] - Demonstrate the circular flow model by engaging in a market simulation, which includes households and businesses and depicts the interactions among them.
4 – E1.0.8 [4] - Explain why public goods (e.g., libraries, roads, parks, the Mackinac Bridge) are not privately owned. (H)

4 – E2.0.1 [4] - Explain how changes in the United States economy impact levels of employment and unemployment (e.g., changing demand for natural resources, changes in technology, changes in competition). (H)
4 – E3.0.1 [4] - Describe how global competition affects the national economy (e.g., outsourcing of jobs, increased supply of goods, opening new markets, quality controls).
[4] - Public Discourse, Decision Making, and Citizen Involvement
4 – P3.1.1 [4] - Identify public issues in the United States that influence the daily lives of its citizens.
4 – P3.1.2 [4] - Use graphic data and other sources to analyze information about a public issue in the United States and evaluate alternative resolutions.
4 – P3.1.3 [4] - Give examples of how conflicts over core democratic values lead people to differ on resolutions to a public policy issue in the United States.
[4] - Persuasive Communication About a Public Issue

4 – P4.2.1 [4] - Develop and implement an action plan and know how, when, and where to address or inform others about a public issue.
4 – P4.2.2 [4] - Participate in projects to help or inform others.
